PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Commercial Sponsorship
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate of the Commonwealth Parliament assembled:
The petition of these residents of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth
That the Australian Broadcasting Corporation provides the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia with the only nation-wide, independent radio and television service.
That the independence of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation must be preserved in the interests of the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Elector-Initiated Referenda
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That although elector-initiated referendums are conducted successfully in such countries as Switzerland and the U.S.A., no such facility exists for Australian citizens.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:
Initiate the necessary action for a referendum to be held to amend the Constitution to provide for such an initiative on the following conditions:

If a specified percentage of voters (such as 2%) sign a petition asking that a referendum be held on a certain question the Federal Government would be obliged to hold that referendum and the result would become law.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that we strongly oppose the introduction of the ``Australia Card'' or any other form of National Identification Numbering System.

We believe that the introduction of a National Identification Numbering System is not only totally unnecessary but is a severe threat to our civil liberties and privacy. We condemn the Government's actions on this matter, particularly as no reasonable nor responsible justifications for the proposal have been forthcoming from the Government.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (EMPLOYEE SHARE ACQUISITIONS) BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Chaney) agreed to:
That the following Bill be introduced: a Bill for an Act to amend certain taxation laws to provide concessions for discounts offered on employee share acquisitions.
Motion (by Senator Chaney) agreed to:
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CHANEY
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I table the explanatory memorandum and seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
The industrial relations policy announced by the coalition in May 1986 has as a principal objective encouragement of a common purpose and mutual interest between employee and employer.

Many elements of the policy are relevant to that objective. One of the policy commitments was to provide a greater incentive for the establishment of schemes whereby employees could buy or acquire shares in the company in which they are employed, and we undertook to provide an appropriate taxation incentive for such schemes.

Before the 1987 election this policy was further developed when we indicated that we would amend the income tax legislation to remove the tax penalty which at present applies where employers issue shares to employees at a discount.

We consider this an important step in encouraging widespread employee share ownership and giving employees the opportunity to own a stake in Australia by owning a stake in the firm for which they work.

Specifically, the Bill limits the application of section 26AAC of the Income Tax Assessment Act so that where employee share schemes comply with the legislative requirements, discounts granted on shares sold to employees will not attract income tax liability as they do at present. Nor will the amount of a discount be liable to capital gains tax or fringe benefits tax. At the moment employees who acquire discounted shares or rights to acquire shares are taxed on the value of the discount either when they acquire the share or right or when they exercise the right. In the latter situation they may find that they are liable to pay tax on an unrealised capital gain. Discounted employee shares are therefore taxed more harshly than, for example, share rights issued to ordinary shareholders.

The tax concession proposed is limited. It will not permit establishment of share schemes merely to minimise tax liabilities nor will it encourage employees to buy shares for short term speculative gain. Instead the changes we propose will remove an anomaly which has penalised employee share schemes and which has deterred companies from setting up such schemes and cause some to abandon schemes.

The Opposition urges the Government to adopt this Bill or provide a positive proposal of its own. The Government has expressed some mild interest in encouraging employee share ownership, but has not yet put forward any firm proposal. Given that the Coalition proposed similar changes in the 1982-83 Budget, the Government certainly has had plenty of opportunity to consider the matter.

The Government may find it difficult to act because of the lack of enthusiasm for employee share ownership among trade union leaders. The enthusiasm of members of the work force to obtain shares, which has been so evident in the United Kingdom, is discouraged by trade union leaders precisely because of the likelihood that share ownership will increase loyalty to and interest in the enterprise.
There is no doubt, however, that it is in the interest of the employees themselves that they should have the opportunity to become part-owners of the enterprise in which they work.

This proposal is not designed to encourage short term or speculative share ownership or trading. Rather, it is intended to help employees identify with their enterprise and to give them a vested interest in ensuring high productivity and in adding value to the enterprise. In introduces an additional element of flexibility in remuneration, and more directly links reward to effort.

From the national perspective, improved productivity and industrial relations at the enterprise level translate into gains in national income and overall living standards. More widespread share ownership and a broader distribution of wealth will also have positive social and economic effects. The change proposed in this Bill, together with the Opposition's commitment to encourage employees to buy shares in privatised enterprises, will assist in promoting wider share ownership in Australia.

The Government argues that employee share ownership will succeed only where other broader participatory initiatives are taken. This can easily degenerate into a futile chicken-and-egg argument, but the evidence suggests that employee share schemes of themselves can contribute enormously to improved industrial relations, productivity and profitability, and worker satisfaction.

For example, studies in the United States of America over the last decade show that companies with employee share ownership schemes consistently out-perform their competitors, generate higher profits and create more new jobs. One study showed that sales and employment growth of companies which introduced employee share ownership plans (ESOPs) almost doubled.
Another study which monitored companies over an 18-year period, showed that companies with employee share ownership schemes grew at around twice the rate of their counterparts without schemes.

Employee share ownership is widespread in a number of Western industrialised countries, especially West Germany, France, and the United Kingdom. Australia has lagged behind. But even here, share plans are becoming popular with, for example, an estimated 60 per cent of the Business Council of Australia's membership either having introduced or considering introduction of share plans. The proportion of wage earners receiving shares is still low at around 2.1 per cent, but according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics this figure has jumped by 50 per cent in one year.

To the extent that increased employee share ownership undermines the `them and us' attitudes which exert such a negative influence on industrial relations in Australia today, the unions might have reason to be uneasy. Their powerful position relies to a significant degree on the existing system which formalises divisions between employees and employers.

Ironically, trade union opposition to measures which are of direct benefit to their members can only enhance the disillusionment many Australian unionists have with trade unions. It would be much more constructive for trade unions-and in their own best interests-to embrace this policy in the interest of their members.

The proposal contained in this Bill is of course only one part of the Opposition's approach to industrial relations. The existing system of compulsory arbitration is too inflexible and increasingly is out of touch with the wishes of workers themselves. The Coalition has set out in detail how it will introduce much greater freedom of choice for employers and employees as to how they conduct their affairs. In short, we will as far as possible return responsibility for industrial relations back where it belongs-the workplace. These fundamental reforms to the industrial relations framework are essential to ensure improved attitudes, productivity and hence scope for increased real wages and living standards.

The changes proposed to taxation of employee share purchases will help ensure that introduction of share schemes is not disadvantaged. We believe that their use will expand as more and more managers realise that their work force is probably their greatest asset and that participatory schemes and financial participation will improve productivity and relations with employees.

The proposal is not viewed by the Opposition as the answer to all our problems, nor even the whole answer to promoting employee share ownership. Other impediments must be addressed such as listing requirements and the companies code which make employee share issues costly and, of course, as mentioned before, we need fundamental change in the industrial relations system. Nevertheless, if implemented, the proposal in this Bill will provide some additional incentive to go down this path.

I would now like to outline the major provisions of the Bill. The Bill proposes to insert a new section 26aa into the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936. The new section will prevent section 26aac operating where `approved share schemes' sell shares or rights to acquire shares to employees at a discount. The maximum percentage discount and the maximum amount of discount that an employee can receive in any year of income will be prescribed by regulation. The Bill has been drafted in this way because the relevant figures will need to be adjusted as money values and other circumstances change. Indicative figures are provided in this speech so that the order of benefits proposed is clear.

An `approved share scheme' is one which must offer shares to employees on a non-discriminatory basis. The only exceptions are that employers may specify a minimum period of services before an employee becomes eligible to buy shares and that the maximum number or value of shares offered to employees may be linked to the income of the employee.

Allowing firms to stipulate a minimum period of service is uncontentious. Employee share schemes cost the company money and they reward employees for their contribution to it. Any attempt to persuade companies to offer shares to employees on their first day of employment would remove one of the principal reasons for companies offering discounted shares to employees. The Opposition also has decided to allow schemes which relate the number of shares or rights offered to employees to the employee's income because this is a very common feature of existing plans which ensures that employees do not overcommit themselves financially. We do not believe that this provision will allow the tax concession to favour higher paid employees because the total amount of tax free discount allowed in any one year will be limited, and, moreover, as we propose, at a quite modest level. Executives who receive a substantial portion of their remuneration in the form of discounted shares would find that they would have to pay tax under section 26aac on any discount in excess of the prescribed amounts. Trusts which purchase shares on an employee's behalf will also be eligible.

Subsection 4 (7) outlines how the proposed tax concession will work. When a company through an approved share scheme sells shares or rights to acquire shares to employees at a discount, and that discount expressed as a percentage of the current market value of the share does not exceed an amount to be prescribed by regulation, the discount will be tax free. Fifteen per cent is considered by the Opposition to be a realistic figure at this stage because that would cover most existing employee share schemes. Importantly, a discount of this magnitude still requires a significant contribution to be made by employees, ensuring that employee share ownership is not viewed merely as a handout.

The Bill is limited to public companies. This limitation by no means indicates that the Opposition considers that only employees of public companies should be encouraged to buy shares. A deliberate decision was taken to restrict this Bill to public companies. We would wish to extend similar measures to private companies and will continue examining ways in which this can be achieved. There are very real practical difficulties in determining the value of untraded shares and this could deter unlisted private companies from taking this course. Profit sharing or bonus payments may be preferable in such cases. Where an approved employee share scheme meets these requirements, the discount given to employees will be tax free and section 26AAC will not apply.

However, employees will be required to keep the share or right to acquire a share for a minimum prescribed period in order to retain the tax concession. The coalition believes that three years would not unduly restrict employees while at the same time encouraging a longer term commitment to the enterprise. Subject to the requirements of the particular scheme, they could sell but if they did normal tax provisions would apply.

One other restriction is outlined in subsections 4 (10) and (11). In any year of income employees will be permitted to receive a maximum amount of discount-to be prescribed by regulation-tax free. For instance, a limit of $450 per annum would allow employees to purchase shares to the value of $3,000 in any one year if they receive 15 per cent discount. If the discount offered were less than 15 per cent obviously the total value of shares which could be purchased would exceed $3,000. Where the discount amount exceeds the prescribed limit in any one year, employees will be required to pay tax under section 26AAC on the excess. Importantly, this restriction on the tax concession not only limits the cost to the Treasury, but also ensures that the concession does not discriminate in favour of higher paid wage and salary earners. The remaining sections of the Bill ensure that the allowed discount is quarantined from capital gains tax and fringe benefits tax provisions.

In summary, the Bill redresses an inequity in the tax system. It overcomes the current discrimination against employee share schemes and allows a limited concession. We are not proposing a tax loophole or a massive drain on the Treasury. That would be counterproductive. At the moment the first $500 of discounts on goods purchased `in-house' by employees from their employers is exempt from fringe benefits tax. It seems more that a little ridiculous that sales of discounted consumption goods are given more lenient tax treatment than discounted sales of shares when the latter offer long term benefits to employers, employees and the nation.

It should also be added that this Bill does not prevent employer companies, including non-public companies, from using the range of employee share ownership schemes which are currently in use but which are outside the scope of this legislation. What is suitable for any particular enterprise and its work force is a matter for commercial decision by the parties. The coalition is not seeking to direct the adoption of such schemes or limit the range of possibilities.

Australia currently has a gross foreign debt of around $112 billion and a net foreign debt of almost $87 billion. Twenty per cent of export earnings is required just to pay the interest bill on that debt. Real wages for Australian workers have fallen for the past two years and real household disposable income declined over 1986-87. Considering these alarming economic realities, surely initiatives which have the proven capacity to promote productivity and to make the work force better off-both financially and in terms of job satisfaction-should not be discouraged for the sake of government-union relations or because of very limited revenue loss in the short term?

In introducing this Bill today I am giving the Government an opportunity to say what it plans to do to ensure that Australian employees are given the same opportunity to improve their standard of living as their counterparts overseas as well as the chance to acquire a stake in their own, and their country's, future.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
Debate (on motion by Senator McKiernan) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Gareth Evans for Senator Tate) agreed to:
That the following Bill be introduced: a Bill for an Act to make various amendments of the statute law of the Commonwealth, and for related purposes.
Motion (by Senator Gareth Evans) agreed to:
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Transport and Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I table the explanatory memorandum and seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill implements, for the last time, the practice of introducing an omnibus Bill into each sittings of the Parliament as an expeditious way of making a large number of non-contentious amendments to legislation.

Some of the amendments made by this Bill tidy up, correct and update existing legislation. Other amendments are of minor policy significance or are matters of routine administration. None of the amendments made by the Bill has a significant financial impact.

As I indicated, this Bill will be the last Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill. From the 1988 Budget sittings technical drafting amendments and repeals of spent and non-operative legislation will be included in a Statute Law Revision Bill. Minor policy amendments will be included in portfolio omnibus Bills.

Honourable senators are familiar with these portfolio omnibus Bills which may include amendments of legislation within a ministerial portfolio or of legislation within specific related subject matters within a portfolio. These Bills will not be subject to the same restrictions as apply to Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bills. The Government has agreed to new guidelines for the inclusion of matters in portfolio Bills which will enable them to include amendments of all legislation within a ministerial portfolio or of related legislation within the portfolio. Major new policy proposals will continue to be implemented, in the first instance, by separate Bills.
Also in future, wherever possible, consequential amendments will be included in the principal Bill rather than in a separate consequential provisions Bill.

In making these changes, the Government is seeking to enhance further opportunities for parliamentary scrutiny of proposed legislation. We have been conscious that some honourable senators and honourable members have expressed concern at the number of amendments, on quite disparate subject matters, contained in some Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bills. These changes are a response to that concern. We believe that the transferring of minor policy amendments from the statute law Bills to portfolios Bills will facilitate parliamentary consideration and debate.

Most of the proposed amendments will be self-evident or sufficiently explained by the explanatory memorandum circulated with the Bill. I propose to confine my comments to addressing the more noteworthy amendments.
Archives Act 1983

The Act currently protects the Commonwealth, authors of documents and the Archives staff who give access to the documents from liability for defamation, infringement of copyright, breach of confidence and criminal proceedings when releasing Commonwealth records in accordance with the public access provisions of the Archives Act. But the Act fails to provide suitable protection for other disclosures made in accordance with the Act. For example the Act at present does not protect Ministers and other authorised persons who give special access to researchers in accordance with section 56 of the Act. The proposed amendments will ensure that protection against civil and criminal liability will apply to all persons involved in properly giving access to records under the Act.
Australian Bicentennial Authority Act 1980

The Attorney-General's Department has advised that the Australian Bicentennial Authority is not subject to the Freedom of Information Act, Ombudsman Act and Archives Act. The Government considers that the Authority should be subject to these Acts.

Accordingly, the amendment of the Australian Bicentennial Authority Act 1980 deems the Authority to be an authority of the Commonwealth for the purpose of the Archives Act 1983 and deems it to be a prescribed authority for the purposes of the Freedom of Information Act 1982 and the Ombudsman Act 1976.
Australian Capital Territory Supreme Court Act 1933
The Australian Capital Territory Supreme Court Act is to be amended to provide for the appointment of a master of the Supreme Court.

There is a pressing need for an additional judicial officer on the Court, which has had three resident judges since 1972. During this period, the ACT's population has increased from about 158,000 to over 260,000. The judges of the Court are also required to serve from time to time on the Federal Court and other tribunals. This situation has resulted in a backlog of civil matters.

The appointment of a master will alleviate this problem. The position will be equivalent to similar positions, which exist with the same title, in State Supreme Courts in the United Kingdom and, from last year, in the High Court of New Zealand.
The master will do a substantial part of the Court's interlocutory work and some other civil matters.

The appointment of a master-which would cost much less than the appointment of another judge-will result in a reduction in the waiting time in the Court and also enable the judges to devote more time to the Court's criminal lists. In the longer term, the judicial work of the Court will be made more attractive, since the judges would be enabled to concentrate on more important matters.
Australian National University Act 1946 and Maritime College Act 1978

The amendments proposed for the Australian National University Act, and the Maritime College Act 1978 are similar in two respects. The amendments clarify the power of the university and the college to form companies to exploit commercially, research and consultancy activities. ANUTECH Pty Ltd is an example of a successful commercial venture. Several State universities and colleges of advanced education have companies or are involved in joint ventures.

The second common aspect of the amendments relates to the disclosure by council members of any direct or indirect pecuniary interest in matters under consideration by the council. The governing councils of these 2 tertiary institutions are concerned that the existing sweeping prohibition that prevents members from being present during deliberations or taking part in decisions after disclosure of a pecuniary interest, can be counterproductive. For example when discussing student administration fees, it would be useful to have the views of the student representative on the council. The amendments proposed will enable each council to make statutes, which are delegated legislation similar to by-laws, to determine conditions under which members may in such circumstances participate in discussions and decision. Persons likely to be affected will be student representatives, academic and general staff who are members of the council.

Further amendments to the Australian National University Act provide for the inclusion of other bodies as well as research schools in the Institute of Advanced Studies. The repeal of other provisions will allow a research school to be organised in more flexible ways.
The flexibility allowed by these changes reflects contemporary organisations in higher education institutions.

Further changes to the Maritime College Act will enable a member of the general staff of the college to be elected to the council under the same conditions as the academic staff representative, and give the college the power to borrow and lend in line with standard provisions prescribed by the Treasurer. There is also included clarification of the college's power to be involved in projects outside Australia.
Other minor amendments are described in the explanatory memorandum.
Economic Planning Advisory Council Act 1983

It is proposed to increase the membership of the council by two people. One will be selected after consultation with such organisations which the Minister considers representative of the professions and the other after consultation with the Australian Council of Trade Unions.
The increased membership reflects a greater emphasis on monitoring prices and incomes policy matters following the abolition of the Advisory Committee on Prices and Incomes.
First Home Owners Act 1983
The Act provides for the making of payments of assistance to eligible persons who are purchasing or constructing their first home.

One proposed amendment will provide for the Secretary to the Department to waive or write off irrecoverable debts arising out of overpayments under the Act and will require the Secretary to report to Parliament on the amounts waived or written off. The purpose is to avoid unnecessary duplication of action under the Audit Act where a decision has been made under the First Home Owners Act.
A further proposed amendment will specify the minimum lease period which will comprise an `approved interest', the basis for application under the scheme.
This will ensure that only long term secured tenure of land similar to an estate in fee simple or a life estate is included in the scheme.

There is an amendment to overcome an anomaly in respect of the income test in the Act which has the effect that the income of some recent arrivals in Australia cannot be tested. The amendment is designed to ensure that recent arrivals in Australia are tested against a full year's income in Australia so that they do not receive an unfair advantage over other Australians by being tested on an income year in which no income that is taxable in Australia was earned. The provision is intended to ensure that all applicants are tested fairly and equitably.

A further provision will enable the making of regulations to allow the disclosure of prescribed information to prescribed people such as the Secretary to the Department of Social Security and the Commissioner of Taxation. The amendment will meet the concerns expressed by the Senate Committee on Regulations and Ordinances by narrowing the existing provision so that is does not trespass unduly on personal rights and liberties.
The remaining amendments are designed to redefine terms to be consistent with other legislation to which the Act is linked.
Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act 1986, Racial Discrimination Act 1975 and Sex Discrimination Act 1984
I propose to deal with the amendments to these three Acts together as several of the amendments are inter-related.

The proposed new section 16 (2a) of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act will remove any doubt about the effectiveness of Commonwealth-State arrangements under which functions of the Commission (mainly those concerned with investigation and conciliation of complaints) are performed by State anti-discrimination and equal opportunity bodies. These arrangements provide a one-stop shopping approach to human rights in the States which is of benefit to complainants and ensures cost savings to the Commonwealth.

Other related amendments are the proposed new section 45 of the Racial Discrimination Act and the deletion of section 48 (2) of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act. New Section 45 will remove an anomaly whereby the Race Discrimination Commissioner and persons dealing with the Commission are protected against civil actions when the Commissioner is exercising the Commission's functions and powers but are not similarly protected when exercising those powers specifically conferred on the Commissioner. The new section 45 is in similar terms to section 111 of the Sex Discrimination Act.

Amendments to section 25z of the Racial Discrimination Act and section 81 of the Sex Discrimination Act will make it clear that where a complaint is brought on behalf of persons other than the person lodging the complaint, remedies may be provided for those other persons as well as the person lodging the complaint.
There are also several amendments of a machinery or drafting nature.
Marriage Act 1961

The Act currently requires the annual publication in the Gazette of lists of authorised marriage celebrants and of persons who are prescribed authorities in relation to marriages. Proposed amendments will remove this requirement and so result in a cost saving by allowing the Minister to approve publication of such lists by making them available, for example, at registry offices in the States and Territories.
There are other amendments of a drafting and technical nature.
National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975

Officers of Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service, Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the Australian Government Solicitor's Office are negotiating a new lease for all Aboriginal land in Kakadu National Park. There is an existing lease over a part of the land. However it is intended to surrender this lease and to enter into a new lease over all aboriginal land in the park.

The proposed amendment to the Act prevents the land from ceasing to be a national park upon surrender of the existing lease and will allow the Director to enter into the new lease without affecting the status of the land and without requiring the Governor-General to amend or revoke the proclamation of the park.
This amendment will apply generally to parks and reserves but at present only Kakadu and Uluru National Parks involve land leased by the Director.

The Act also specifies that the Director cannot enter into a contract involving the payment or receipt of an amount exceeding $50,000 without the approval of the Minister. This amount has not changed since the Act was proclaimed in 1975 although the real value of this amount has been substantially eroded through inflation.

In relation to the capital works program it has become necessary to approach the Minister repeatedly to seek permission to enter into or vary contracts. This results in unwarranted administrative costs and can also cause problems due to the strict time limits often encountered under the tendering process.

Current policy guidelines for Commonwealth statutory authorities and government business enterprises specify $100,000 as an appropriate limit for non-commercial authorities. As there is no administrative mechanism to enable the Minister to vary the amount prescribed, an amendment to the Act is necessary.

A provision enabling the Minister to prescribe a higher amount has been inserted. This type of provision has been incorporated in recent legislation, and it obviates the need for future amendment of the Act simply to increase the figure. Such regulations are of course, subject to the scrutiny of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: TEXTILES, CLOTHING AND FOOTWEAR DEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 22 March.
Clause 10 (Report on TCF industries' matter etc.).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee has reached the stage where it is considering clause 10 (4) of the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority Bill, which is a Bill to establish the new quango to implement the Government's textiles, clothing and footwear plan. As I have indicated, the Opposition is of the view that the Bill, as originally presented, contained many draconian powers-and this is one of them. The Government has agreed to delete and/or amend some of the draconian powers. The Government proposes, in relation to clause 10 (4), to add some qualifying words. Let me explain what clause 10 (4) does. It gives the Authority a power to give to the Minister:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a report on any instance that it considers is an instance of failure by a person involved in any of the TCF industries to act consistently with the policies of the Commonwealth Government with respect to those industries . . .

Madam Temporary Chairman, just imagine what a massive power that is-a power to report that some company is not acting `consistently with the policies of the Government'. The Law Council of Australia wrote a letter to us and enclosed the advice of Mr Garry Downes, QC, who says:

The most disturbing part of the Bill is cl. 10, and , in particular cl. 10 (4). The clause gives the Authority power to inquire into a number of matters relating to the question of whether Commonwealth Government policies are being achieved.
He goes on to say:

Persons subject to Australian law have an obligation to abide by that law. That seems to me, however, generally, to be the proper limit of legislative interference. It does not seem to me that it is proper for Government to seek to impose obligations to comply with Government policy.

He then goes on to give reasons for being very critical of that situation. All that the Government proposes to do in relation to clause 10 (4) is to add a provision that, before the Authority dobs in some company or some individual for failure to act consistently with the Government's policies, it must advise the person that he is about to be reported. The Opposition is of the view that that is totally inadequate. Accordingly, I have moved:
(2) Page 7, subclause 10 (4), lines 29 to 36, leave out the subclause.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats cannot support this amendment by the Opposition for two quite good reasons. Honourable senators will notice that the purpose for which this Authority is created is to help in the better formulation of policy in relation to textiles, clothing and footwear development. The Development Authority will need to develop strategies. Of course, they will be developed in conformity with consultations with the industry and then there will need to be feedback to the Authority to discover whether the industry is conforming with those strategies.

SPEECH.PARA: To take this subclause out would mean that the Authority would not be in a position to ascertain whether a part of the industry was not conforming with a strategy which had been developed. Moreover, clause 10 contains no sanctions whatsoever. It does not say that an illegal act is being performed which requires some sanction. It simply states that a report may be prepared and it then goes on to set various conditions for that. That would seem to me to be absolutely appropriate to fulfil one of the essential functions for this Development Authority. Without it, it would not be possible for the Authority to discharge properly its duties.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 10 epitomises why the Opposition is so bitterly opposed to this legislation to establish a Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority. As Senator Lewis has said, this clause is but one of several examples in the Bill giving the Authority draconian inquisitorial powers. I am surprised that the Australian Democrats see fit to support it. These powers are completely unnecessary for the monitoring and administration of the textile, clothing and footwear sectoral plan. The clause gives the Authority the power to publish reports on whether people in the industry are acting consistently with the Government's textile, clothing and footwear policy-not whether they are failing to comply with legislation, but with policy. So much for the rule of law! Totalitarian arbitrary rule is already with us in this legislation. The policy of the party must be obeyed. Talk about shades of Stalinist Russia! If one fails to comply with the policy, that failure will be published, with the obvious aim of pressure being brought to bear to fall into line. Again, it should be emphasised that no law has been broken and no charges laid, just a policy not complied with. An authority with such power should not be contemplated, and this legislation, as the Opposition has said, should be thrown out. It raises questions about the whole role of the Authority.

SPEECH.PARA: The heavily protected segments of the textile, clothing and footwear industry view the Authority as their guarantee that additional assistance will be provided if, once the plan is implemented, production falls by more than an average of 15 per cent. We are not told why such an authority would have a monopoly on the expertise required to determine whether it was the plan or some other factors which caused such a production fall. There are already a large number of people and several organisations that could take on this proposed function, including the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Industry Council, which is largely government financed; sections of the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce; the Industries Assistance Commission; or other government and industry bodies associated with the textile, clothing and footwear industry-or indeed the industry could be left alone to be self-regulatory.

Of course many factors other than the plan could contribute to a fall in production, including changes in fashion, technology and currency values, especially when the excessive protection of these industries actually increases over about the first four years of the plan. So where is the need for yet another bureaucratic, expensive monitoring authority? The options developed for post-1988 textile, clothing and footwear assistance in the Industries Assistance Commission report were designed to be simple to understand and to provide a predictable, invariant policy environment for the textile, clothing and footwear sector during the transition to the chosen target rate. Because the proposals were designed to specify all the elements of the transition mechanism in advance, the Commission said in its report that no monitoring authority would be required under any of its proposals. Indeed, it was of the view that the introduction of a monitoring authority would add undesirable uncertainty to the post-1988 textile, clothing and footwear policy environment.

Undoubtedly there will be changes in the economic environment faced by the textile, clothing and footwear firms after 1988. For instance, fashion changes are an integral part of the textile, clothing and footwear market, creating opportunities for innovative designs while reducing demand for superseded products. It is difficult to envisage what the role of a monitoring authority would be in relation to fashion changes. Presumably at best it could observe progressive firms initiating and taking advantage of fashion changes to the detriment of less dynamic firms. Clearly it would not be in the interests of improving international competitiveness to inhibit growing, innovative enterprises by compensating firms which could not keep up.

Technological change is continuing throughout the textile, clothing and footwear sector. Industry participants' knowledge of recent and foreseeable technological changes, and the rapidity with which they are taking advantage of recent developments, is impressive. Firms invest in new capital because they assess that the investment will give them a competitive edge over their rivals, both domestic and overseas, or at least enable them to match their competition. Again, it is difficult to envisage what role a monitoring authority would have with regard to technological change. Participants are in the best position to assess whether the introduction of new capital would be cost-effective.

Exchange rate changes are a fact of life for all industries competing with overseas products or using imported inputs. Movements in exchange rates are one of the chief mechanisms which encourage changes in the structure of the economy in response to adjustments in Australia's competitive position compared with our trading partners. They bring the Australian economy back into balance as economic circumstances change.

To try to insulate particular industries or activities from the adverse or beneficial effects of changes in exchange rates would introduce undesirable instability and uncertainty into the assistance structure of the economy as a whole. Also, it would increase the amount of adjustment required by all other industries that are not similarly assisted. Furthermore, to provide all industries which are disadvantaged by exchange rate movements with compensatory assistance would defeat the underlying role of exchange rate variations which serve to induce economy wide adjustments to changes in the domestic and external trading environment. Such a policy could set in train a spiral of exchange rate change, further compensatory assistance and further exchange rate adjustments. As it would be undesirable to provide any compensation to the textile, clothing and footwear sector for exchange rate changes, it is difficult to foresee any purpose for a monitoring authority. The effects of devaluation and revaluation on particular parts of the Australian economy is well known. No industries should be given special compensation for such changes even during periods when their assistance levels are being altered.

The textile, clothing and footwear industry has claimed that a monitoring authority is required to advise the Government as to whether developments occurring are compatible with the achievement of the objectives of the program. But it is likely that changes in the rate of structural adjustment would reflect the most economically desirable path of adjustment rather than indicating that anything was amiss in achieving the objectives of the program.

It would be unwise for a monitoring authority to apply indirect pressure to hasten the rate of adjustment reductions in the initial years of the program if the adjustment was slower than anticipated. On the other hand an observed increase in the rate of structural change could well reflect the cumulative effects of many individual decisions on the best time to discontinue particular activities. Consequently, the introduction of a monitoring authority to advise on the rate and nature of structural change during the program would be unnecessary and highly undesirable. In its 1986-87 annual report the Australian Manufacturing Council noted with considerable concern the Government's intention to establish such an authority. It felt that there was considerable overlap between its proposed activities and those of the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Industry Council. It felt that this could result in unnecessary duplication and waste of taxpayers' money.

Surely the Government should accept this enormous weight of evidence and withdraw not just clause 10 but the whole legislation as the Opposition has proposed. The Government's determination to proceed with clause 10 in the light of our proposed amendment must raise questions about the efficacy of the whole textile, clothing and footwear sectoral plan. What sort of plan is it that requires such draconian provisions as are contained in clause 10? While the plan reduces current effective rates of protection over about seven years they will still be excessively high and average between 50 and 60 per cent at the end of the plan. Quite simply, the plan does not go far enough in reducing costs imposed on exporters by this protective regime.

Excessive protection in all forms, but particularly in the form of tariffs, is obviously detrimental to economic growth and wealth creation. It insulates an economy from change which is essential to real growth. Furthermore, it insulates particular industries which need to adapt to changing international conditions to increase their productivity and to develop and apply new technology. Protection is a cost which will be borne by the community in one form or another, so the alleged benefits should always be carefully analysed. Ultimately this protection is paid by the export industries. This is because the costs of production which are associated with tariff protection are passed down the line until they can be passed no further. Of course, the buck stops with export industries which have to sell their products on world markets under free competition. They cannot set their own prices on those world markets. Hence it is finally the exporters who have to bear the full cost of tariff protection. This means in particular that Australia's rural industries bear about half the tariff cost burden.

Not only does protection remain at an excessive effective rate of 60 per cent at the end of this scheme but, as I said earlier, it actually increases above its current exorbitant rate for the first few years. This will not only increase the burden on exporters and especially the farming community, which can no longer afford to carry it, but will result in increased costs to consumers. While it is Australia's exporters who finally foot the bill for protecting these industries, because of the flow-on effect of the cost impact in our domestic economy, at least in the short run consumers also bear the costs because there is some lag in the flow-on effect. The Prices Surveillance Authority has calculated that there will be a 20 per cent increase in the price of clothing as a result of this plan. This fact serves to reinforce just how out of touch this Hawke Labor Government has become with the people it claims to represent.

It is the poor who are increasingly paying the costs to consumers of excessive protection. The textiles, clothing and footwear and motor vehicle manufacturing industries are two of the most highly protected segments. Whereas the wealthiest 30 per cent in our community spend, on average, about 9 per cent of their household income on textiles, clothing and footwear and motor vehicles, the poorest 30 per cent spend 13 to 14 per cent of their income on those products. Australia's poor deserve better from this Government than being forced to bear the brunt of the excessive protection it gives to certain industries. On a number of occasions the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) have waxed eloquent with great rhetoric about their willingness to take tough decisions. Senator Walsh has berated them more than once for being unwilling to take the really hard decisions necessary for the future economic welfare of this country and, as I demonstrated a moment ago, to ease the burden on the really productive and the poor at the same time. This plan is evidence of that unwillingness. One of the three members of the Industries Assistance Commission inquiry into Australia's textiles, clothing and footwear industries is quoted as saying:

The final deal that Senator Button had come up with was as good as could be expected in the circumstances. However, if this was the best deal he could come up with, it said a lot about the political circumstances in this country.

One assumes that when Labor Ministers refer to hard decisions, they mean decisions in our long term interests which may cause short term unpopularity. If, as is evident in the textiles, clothing and footwear plan, the Government was unwilling to take a sufficiently hard decision in political circumstances when it had some measure of popularity some months ago, what chance does this country have of decisions being taken for the rest of its term of office which will be to the benefit of this country, now that it has so clearly lost the support of the majority of Australians'.

Quite simply, this plan does not result in a sufficient pace of change in ensuring that the textiles, clothing and footwear industries become internationally competitive. The plan should have had the goal of reducing the effective rate of protection for these industries to the order of 20 to 25 per cent, which is still well above the rate for manufacturing industry as a whole, rather than the 50 to 60 per cent which will apply. After all, the level of 20 to 25 per cent would still be somewhat more than double the effective rate of protection for all industry-primary, secondary and tertiary. This would not only reduce to a more reasonable level the massive cost to Australia's economy of the excessive protection afforded these industries but also ensure that they become internationally competitive and, therefore, able to earn valuable export dollars for Australia. With those doubts about the plan, but more particularly these significant doubts about the efficacy of the Authority, the Opposition opposes not only the legislation in total but this clause in particular. I support the amendment moved by Senator Lewis.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —I intend to restrict my remarks to clause 10 and to deal specifically with clause 10 (4). In formally supporting the amendment moved by Senator Lewis, I reiterate the point he made that the Bill contains draconian powers. Clause 10 (4) provides that the Authority may prepare a report on any industry in the textiles, clothing and footwear area on the question of whether or not it has acted consistently with the policies of government. Further, under clause 10 (4) (b), it may publish that report. The proposed Government amendment would simply add a provision that nobody may have that report about him or her published unless he or she is first informed. I suggest that that is a little like getting ready to hit someone over the head with a bit of 10 x 4 and telling him about it first. It really does not assuage the pain very much. Quite frankly, the proposed amendment in no way removes the concerns that the Opposition has about that power which is being given to the Authority under clause 10 (4).

SPEECH.PARA: I was interested and disappointed to hear Senator Coulter say that the Australian Democrats would not be supportive of our amendment because the Authority helps in the formulation of policy. Somehow he managed to reason that the deletion of clause 10 (4) would, in some way, prevent that occurring. The earlier subclauses of clause 10 provide for the Authority to make reports to the Government and to give advice. Clause 10 (4) specifically enables a report to be made and the publication of that report, which can clearly be made to the detriment of a small or large business which it affects.

The textile, clothing and footwear industries embrace many small business people. As we often hear, small business is the big employer in Australia. It is not hard to see that such a report could force a small business enterprise to the wall. To draw an analogy, it might be something like the action that was taken by consumer organisations against the manufacturers of pate that resulted in them being unfairly forced to the wall. We say that the inclusion of a proposed new subclause (5) in no way ameliorates the draconian nature of the provisions of clause 10 (4).

The point that it is also to monitor policy and to attest as to whether or not industry is following government policy is, again, a point that I find very difficult to live with. Requiring people to comply with the law is one thing. The law is certain, and that is the benefit that the common law affords us in this land. But if a person is required simply to comply with policy which is totally uncertain and may change from time to time, then he has no certainty as to the application for planning purposes to use effectively invested capital and plan for the future of the enterprise that he may be conducting.

I have another concern, too. The Bill, in a different clause, provides for the establishment of the Authority, as is to be expected. Five people are to be appointed. However, there is no provision anywhere in the Bill as to what sort of people may be appointed to that Authority. If we look at the sorts of appointments that are made by this Government, we note the appointment to the Trade Practices Commission of Mr Alan Asher, about whom I have spoken in this place before, a man who is anti-business. Who are we going to expect to be appointed to this Authority? Perhaps Barrie Unsworth, who is in need of a job, might be a good chairman. Perhaps John Halfpenny might be considered suitable. Nowhere is there a restriction laid down or a definition given of the sort of people who might be appointed to this Authority, who would then have the power over small and large industries to ascertain whether or not, in their learned opinion, a business is complying with the policy, almost on a day to day basis, that the Government has put in place, and then have the power to publish. The only saver that the Government is prepared to give is that those concerned should be told first. As I said, that would in no way ease the pain if a person were subjected to the sort of report that could effectively put his or her business to the wall.

Many other parts of this Bill concern me. Perhaps I will have the opportunity to speak to other clauses as we move through it. But I think it is important to place two matters on the record and to recap. Firstly, the so-called saver in subclause (5) in no way ameliorates the basic flaw of clause 10 (4), which gives this draconian power to an authority the composition and peopling of which we are unaware. Secondly, the argument put forward by the Democrats as to why they are not supportive of our amendment simply does not ring true. Senator Coulter said that this would stop the Authority being involved in the formulation of policy. That is simply not true. The rest of the Bill provides quite adequately for that. With those two statements on the record, I ask the Committee to consider seriously whether or not justice is being done to the industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was surprised to hear Senator Chapman talk about the objection by industry to this legislation. SPEECH.PARA: I would like to make a brief comment on a point made by Senator Bishop. Although the term `draconian' keeps coming through, I cannot find anything draconian about this measure at all. The Authority may become aware of that the person will be informed that the report has been made and will have the opportunity to feed countervailing information to the Authority. Presumably, out of that there may be some modification of the plan. Clause 9 (6) provides:
A plan, whether or not it has come into force, may be varied by the Authority with the approval of the Minister.

So, the legislation provides for the possibility of feedback. Therefore, although the term `draconian' keeps coming up, I cannot find anything particularly draconian about that clause. That is why the Australian Democrats will be supporting the clause. I was interested to hear two names mentioned in relation to the appointment of people to the Authority.
