TALK.START.PARA: —We now come to a somewhat difficult situation in that I wish to move that the whole of part V be deleted. I understand from the Clerk that I should be dealing with it clause by clause. In other words, I should move for the deletion of clauses 45, 46 and 47. It has been suggested that I take the debate on clause 45 as a debate on my motion that the whole of part V be deleted, because if I do not succeed with the deletion of clause 45 I have not succeeded with the motion to delete the whole of part V. I am sure the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) will follow that.

SPEECH.PARA: On the other hand, I draw attention to the fact that if I lose my amendment to delete part V I will move an amendment to clause 45 (2) to delete the words `in the public interest'. I seek from the Minister some acknowledgment that he will give me leave, if I lose on the deletion of the whole of clause 45, to move for the deletion of the words `in the public interest' from clause 45 (2).

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.
—I thank the Minister for his consideration in that regard. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That clause 45 be deleted.

I have formally moved for the deletion of clause 45 as a procedure for the deletion of the whole of part V. Part V contains the clauses which relate to the conduct of formal inquiries. Senator Coulter referred to the fact that we, on this side of the chamber, have been referring to the draconian powers of the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority. It is part V that contains the draconian powers. In my view the part will continue to contain the draconian powers notwithstanding the Government's proposed amendments which the Minister, having given further consideration to the representations which have been made to him about this part, has agreed to introduce.

The first sub clause of clause 45 says that whenever the Authority conducts an inquiry the inquiry shall be held in public. The Authority may, under clause 7, conduct such inquiries as it considers necessary for the proper performance of its functions. Senator Coulter was critical of us for referring to clause 10(4) as being draconian. If honourable senators read clause 10(4), which relates to the power to report on some person or company which is acting inconsistently with the policies of the Commonwealth Government, and if they appreciate that the Authority may report on that, and if they then look at clause 7 and see that the Authority may conduct such inquiries as it considers necessary for the proper performance of its functions, they will appreciate that the Authority may conduct an inquiry into some person as to whether he is acting consistently with the Government's policies. If that is not a draconian power of inquiry I do not know what is.

The legislation then goes on to say that such an inquiry shall be conducted in public. A person who is trying to get on with his own business and who no doubt has very substantial funds invested in a company he has worked with all his life is, together with his employees, perhaps, to be examined in public as to whether or not he is acting consistently with Government policies or on some other matter that the Authority wishes to inquire into. An amendment is to be moved to the effect that, if he does not come before the inquiry, he will not be subject to massive fines or imprisonment, but if he comes before the inquiry he will be sworn to give evidence on oath and will be examined in public under clause 45(1).

I find this quite horrifying. I do not imagine that the Government will allow the Authority to drag some trade union official before such an inquiry. If the Government had been prepared to allow that to happen it may very well have allowed the Steel Industry Authority to inquire into what is happening at Port Kembla in relation to the trade union movement. I presume the Government's attitude is that trade union officials should be exempt from these sorts of inquiries. I note that the Steel Industry Authority has not conducted this sort of public inquiry in relation to the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd (BHP) and the steel industry. It has certainly reported in public on certain things, but I do not recall it taking on BHP or the trade union officials connected with the steel industry at a public hearing. The TCF Development Authority will be dealing with small people-small businessmen and small businesses. It will have no difficulty at all in being bureaucratic in its approach to them and, as I said, it will conduct these inquiries in public.

Clause 45(2) states that the Authority may conduct an inquiry in private if it is of the opinion that the circumstances are such that it is necessary or desirable in the public interest to do so-not in the interests of the industry, not in the interests of not exposing the manufacturer to ridicule or contempt, and not because it is concerned about exposing to the public, to the media, confidential information about a company's affairs. The Authority is entitled to hold an inquiry in private only if it is considerd necessary or desirable in the public interest to do so.

I say to Senator Coulter that if he reads all those things together he will see why the coalition parties have been describing this legislation as draconian. It will remain draconian after the Government's amendments have been carried. The Government now proposes to remove among other clauses in part V, the clauses which would enable the Authority to bring witnesses before it to give evidence, on penalty of $1,000 or six months imprisonment, and, if a witness refuses to be sworn or to answer questions, to impose a penalty of $1,000 or six months imprisonment.

Frankly, there is no need for this Authority to conduct formal inquiries. After all, the Minister, in his second reading speech, said that this Authority would not be intrusive. He went on to say that most of the information the Authority would need for the purposes of its report would be available from the Australian Bureau of Statistics. The Authority will be using public information in formulating its report. Notwithstanding that, this whole part V relates to formal inquiries. I put it to the Committee that there is simply no need for the whole of part V. The Authority would be well able to implement the Government's plan. As the Minister says, the most important aspect of the Authority's role is to implement the Government's plan and to act as a monitoring authority without the need for a power to conduct formal inquiries.

I am sure the Minister does not intend this to be some legalistic body. I believe he is not going to appoint as chairman of this body some Queen's Counsel, such as Mr Fitzgerald in Queensland, who can conduct an inquiry in the nature of a royal commission; he is proposing to appoint lay people to the Authority. It is well known that when lay people get themselves involved in conducting some sort of formal inquiry whereby witnesses give evidence, on oath, they do not have the legal background to recognise the safeguards necessary to protect people's simple civil rights. Because they lack the legal training, they are inclined to encroach on people's simple civil liberties in ways that those of us who have had some training in the law find horrifying and indeed in ways which, when the public realises what is happening, the public finds horrifying. But by then it is too late and the damage has been done.
So I say to the chamber that this Bill would be a far better Bill if the whole of part V were deleted, and accordingly I formally oppose clause 45.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —In proposing that the whole of part V be deleted, Senator Lewis has really drawn to the attention of the Committee the reasons why we have been using the term `draconian'-a term which Senator Coulter finds difficulty in coming to terms with. When a Bill threatens the ability of people to earn their living, it can be very aptly described as draconian. It is interesting that in making a proper case against this legislation, as Senator Lewis did, it is necessary to read various clauses of it together to get its full impact. It is interesting to read, for instance, the definition clause of the Bill. It contains no definition of policy, which is central to the thrust of the Bill. I pointed out when I spoke on clause 10 (4) that the requirement is that people comply with policy, not the law, and that there is the ability to change policy almost on a day to day basis and therefore there is no certainty.

SPEECH.PARA: Part V, in the form in which it originally came into the chamber, before the Government's amendments were foreshadowed, was horrendous. It would have created powers that could well have been exercised by the Court of Star Chamber. I acknowledge that in taking some of those powers out the Minister has recognised that that sort of thing is just not acceptable in Australia. But many provisions remain which are also not acceptable to the Opposition.

I draw attention to clause 54, in which protection is given to employees who are going to give evidence before the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority, or the inquiry, or to people who have in fact given evidence. There is a provision to protect the employee from action being taken against him or her by the employer, but the onus of proof concerning any action that may have been taken with regard to the employment of someone who is a prospective witness, or is in fact a witness, lies with the employer. There is no protection given to an employer concerning anybody who might appear before an inquiry and for whatever reason gives evidence which is malicious or vindictive, or involves any of those sorts of things which are quite foreseeable from time to time in business. I find the fact that the onus of proof rests on the defendant to establish that any action taken by an employer against somebody who may have also been a witness unacceptable.

Senator Lewis also pointed out, very strongly, our objection to the words `public interest' remaining in clause 45 (2) because it precludes the Authority from conducting an inquiry in circumstances other than in the public interest. As Senator Lewis pointed out, there can be a whole host of reasons why such an inquiry, if it is to take place, ought to be held in private.

One of the things that concern me most about the Bill is that although it is part of the Government's whole thrust to make business more competitive, which is something I wholly approve of, it is prepared to address only one side of the equation. It is prepared to look only at overt protection; it is prepared to look only at reducing tariffs and bounties and so on. It is not prepared to look at the other side of the equation, at the impediments to efficiency and competition that come from the likes of work practices and actions by the trade union movement. I can understand why the Government is reluctant, and in fact refuses, to take such action. Historically the Australian Labor Party is the political wing of the trade union movement and, therefore, is really taking the soft option in attacking protection. In my view, if we are to look honestly at making industry in Australia more competitive, we have to look at both sides of the equation. That means the union side of it as well as the employer side.

We proposed that clause 10 (4) be deleted. Subsequently, having lost on that, we agreed to support the amendment concerning subclause (5). It is important to put into this part of my speech, so that everything remains in context, the fact that now, under the Bill, if somebody is to be reported upon for not complying with Government policy that report may not be made public until that person has been told. Nowhere in the Bill is any provision made for that person who is advised that he is about to be reported upon to have any recourse, any way of refuting or rebutting the report that is about to be published. As I said before, it is really like telling somebody that he is about to be hit over the head with a piece of four by two. It does not really make the pain any less.

My particular concerns with this Bill lie very largely with the fact that we see the Government once again exercising the soft option. I do not see that the Government's policies, whatever they may be, however they are determined and however they are communicated to the Authority for it to deliberate upon, can be effective unless both sides of the equation, as I set out earlier, are addressed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was rather surprised to hear Senator Bishop say that the Government would not use this proposed section of the legislation against a trade union person. She seems to be assuming that the Labor Government will be in power indefinitely and that the legislation will never be administered by the parties now in opposition. I would have thought that if this Act comes into force at some time in the future, it may well be administered by the present Opposition parties. It would certainly be within their power to exercise these clauses with the even-handedness with which Senator Bishop says it may not be administered in the next two years. The Australian Democrats will not be supporting the motion to delete the whole of part V because this sets up the mechanisms for formal inquiries and, as I have indicated earlier, the conduct of those inquiries seems to be an essential part of the function of the Development Authority.

SPEECH.PARA: I draw the Committee's attention to the Steel Industry Authority Act. It certainly seems as though this clause has been lifted verbatim out of that Act. Section 21, part IV of the Steel Industry Authority Act of 1983, uses precisely the same words as we find in part V of this Bill. I do not hear the Opposition objecting to those words, although Senator Lewis has defended them in that situation because he says that the steel industry is different from the footwear, textiles and clothing industries in that it is dealing with one large industry--

TALK.START.PARA: —One large company.
—Yes, one large company. I looked through the Steel Industry Authority Act to find out the functions of the Steel Industry Authority. They are:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . to monitor and analyse steel industry matters and, where it thinks it appropriate, conduct inquiries, report to the Minister and make recommendations to the Minister on such matters.

Among those matters we find the standards and product quality attained or set by the steel industry and the services that the steel industry provides to the buyers of steel. That surely would involve large numbers of very small users of steel around Australia and might well involve the same sorts of industries that a large wool or cotton producer would be dealing with when dealing with small clothing manufacturers. Moreover, section 7 (2) (q) says:
. . . matters relating to the steel industry that the Minister, by notice in writing, refers to the Authority.

That gives the Steel Industry Authority very wide powers to carry out these inquiries, the wording of which is precisely the same as the wording we have in this Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority Bill. The Democrats would like the Minister to comment on the alternative suggestion made by Senator Lewis in relation to deletion of the words `in the public interest'. I accept that this wording has been carried over absolutely verbatim from the Steel Industry Authority Act and it may well have been carried over from other Acts. I am not really convinced that there is a need for those words. If the intention of this whole part is to allow the Authority broadly to carry out inquiries in public into a number of aspects of the industry, it is unwise to tie the hands of the Authority. I remind the Committee of the wording. Clause 45 (1) states:
Subject to subsection (2), an inquiry shall be held in public.
Quite clearly there is an overriding injunction on the Authority to hold its inquiries in public. Subsection (2) states:
The Authority may hold the whole or part of an inquiry in private if, in the opinion of the Authority, the circumstances are such that it is necessary or desirable in the public interest to do so.

It ties the hands of the Authority in that if, in the opinion of the Authority, it were in the private interest or some interest other than the broadly defined public interest-whatever that might mean-the Authority is constrained. It seems to be desirable to leave the Authority with the power to determine those circumstances under which an inquiry should be held in public; in other words, to abrogate for particular reasons that overriding injunction we find in subsection (1). At this moment I am leaning towards the support of the Opposition amendment with respect to subsection (2) in that I believe the legislation would be better if the Authority were free and then the wording would be, `the circumstances are such that it is necessary or desirable to do so', leaving out the words `in the public interest'. Those words have simply been carried over, perhaps in a fairly lazy way. There may not be a very good reason for leaving them in the legislation. I would very much like to hear the Minister's opinion on those four words.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened to the various comments that have been made about this clause and part V of the legislation. First, the Government has foreshadowed a number of amendments to this part of the legislation which result from representations made by the industry and similar representations having been made to the Opposition and to the Australian Democrats. The representations made have been taken up in the Government's amendments and the industry does not want to be protected by my colleague Senator Lewis any further than the Government amendments go. Here is a champion of some mythical industries or firms which are not identified. I understand his role and what he is saying about these sorts of provisions. But, having said that, we do not agree. A lot of comments that have been made, particularly by Senator Bishop, are comments which might sound all right but are not founded in any sense in experience or knowledge of these industries. These industries have always been subject, because they are highly protected industries, to government inquiries and committees of one kind or another which have looked at the pattern of events and so on in order to adjust protection regimes and so on.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not want to take the matter any further than just to say that experience over recent years, particularly in the life of the plan which the Fraser Government brought in, suggests that much misleading information has been given by companies to governments on such matters as production levels, likely market trends and likely levels of imports. Much misinformation has been given by some companies-not the industry as a whole-and has been designed to achieve particular results in terms of adjustment to the protection regime. It is not fair that industries which are highly protected and impose a cost burden on consumers should do that to the community. It is not fair for companies to give that sort of misleading information. It is all very well to make speeches about draconian provisions and so on. They are not draconian provisions, as they will be amended if the Government amendments are carried out, and it is not fair for companies to behave in that way.

If the Government is to provide this level of protection and other assistance which is foreshadowed in the textiles, clothing and footwear development plan, it is not fair for people to make those sorts of misrepresentations. Any government, authority or body which has the responsibility of looking after the public interest should at least be in a position to deal with those situations if and when they arise. That is a very important point to remember. Senator Lewis made a political point. He said that the Authority will not have the unions coming before it; it will just deal with little employers and all that sort of stuff. He said, `Look at the Steel Industry Authority. It never hauled the unions before it to look at what was happening in Port Kembla'. That is just not correct. These bodies have to act in a real situation. It is no good carrying on high blown public inquiries if, by doing that, we will not influence events. The Steel Industry Authority obtained a great deal of information from trade unions and from the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd about what happened in Port Kembla and that was reported in its report upon which Senator Lewis relied in earlier discussions in the Senate. The Chairman of the Steel Industry Authority is a very competent businessman with wide industrial experience. He is concerned in difficult situations to produce the best results. The membership of this Authority will be of the same kind. It is important to get the best possible results in terms of output, productivity and good labour relations. All these things are immensely important in the context of dealing with an industry.

Senator Bishop said that, in the task of trying to make Australian industries more competitive, the Government was concentrating on only one aspect-that is, reducing levels of protection, reducing bounties and things of that kind. She said that we have to look at the union side as well as the employer side. I totally agree with that. She said that we had to address things such as work practices. In the textile industry particularly, the problem in negotiating the second tier wage agreement was that the employers said: `We do not have any work practices which upset us here'. That is what the companies said.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about on the wharves for exporters?

—With the greatest respect, we are talking about the textile, clothing and footwear industries. I totally agree with the honourable senator about the wharves but we are not debating the wharves at the moment. We are talking about what happens in the textile, clothing and footwear industries and the honourable senator was saying that work practices are an issue. If we could get the companies to make it an issue in the second tier wage negotiations that would be good, but most of them said, `We really do not have problems with work practices in these industries'; and that is true.
—But what industry is not isolated from the problem on the wharves, which affects them as well?

—The textiles, clothing and footwear legislation unhappily does not relate to the wharves and that is what we are talking about here. It is conceded that there are problems on the waterfront, and those are being addressed in a different way; but we are not debating that today.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the important things about this sort of authority is that if we are to produce the best results in terms of productivity, in terms of a whole range of issues, such as the use of capital equipment and so on, we really have to have a consultative approach to this sort of thing. If we just take, for example, the textile industry, which is highly capital intensive, there have been no problems. The industry and the unions, finally, after a long period of negotiation, went to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission together to change the awards in order to provide for 24-hour operation of plants. That is what we want to achieve. The point I am simply trying to make is that it is no good alleging things which are not correct.

TALK.START.PARA: —If the industry is going to be highly capital intensive--
—Order! Senator Stone will have an opportunity, in an orderly fashion in committee, to ask questions when the Minister has finished his explanation.
—Will the Minister accept my question?
—I did not hear it. What was it?
—I was about to ask it.
—Order! I ask Senator Stone to ask his question at the appropriate time.

—In summary, the amendments to part V moved by the Government take out those provisions which the industry regarded as draconian, if we use Senator Bishop's words, or which it did not like. Senator Lewis is left with a sail which does not have much wind in it, except for his own wind. The new provisions, as they now stand, are very reasonable in the sorts of circumstances which I have outlined.

SPEECH.PARA: The only other comment I want to make concerns the use of the expression `in the public interest' in clause 45 (2). What it is desired to protect there are matters of commercial confidence. Senator Lewis made that point and I totally agree with him. The Authority will have to take into account from time to time matters which are commercially confident. I would have thought that the expression `in the public interest' embraced the notion of commercial confidentiality-that is to say, in administering any situation like this it should be an accepted norm that it is in the public interest that matters which are commercially confident are so treated and that the Authority will behave in that way. That is what I think it means.

TALK.START.PARA: —But that doesn't necessarily mean it means that.

—It does not necessarily mean that but, once again, I think that is what it is intended to mean and that is the way people are likely to behave. If any company says to the Authority, `We want this matter dealt with in private because we will give you some numbers about our investment', or something like that, that would be done, and that would be regarded as being in the public interest because `the public interest' embraces the notion of this thing working well from the point of view of the companies concerned.
—You do not know that it will be treated in that way; you only hope.

—I will not respond to this barrage of law school argument; I am trying to deal with a serious point. I think that is the way it operates; that is the way it has always operated with these types of authorities. These provisions are similar to provisions in the Automotive Industry Authority legislation. A mass of commercial in confidence material is dealt with by that Authority, involving enormous investments, enormous decisions in terms of investment and a whole range of commercially sensitive information. Not one company in that industry, be it a plant manufacturer or a component producer, has ever uttered a complaint about any information that has been given to that Authority not being dealt with properly. That is the way it ought to happen and that is the way it will happen. We reject the amendment moved by Senator Lewis. I take it that the honourable senator regards this clause as his test case, as it were, and that we can deal with part V in the context of this clause.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Temporary Chairman, I would like to ask Senator Button the question which, no doubt properly, you prevented me from putting in the course of his remarks. If I understood Senator Button's remarks correctly, he asserted in response to my colleague Senator Bishop that there were no problems with restrictive practices in the textile industry, which I think is the industry he was talking about in particular, of which even the managers could speak. Senator Button said that this was a very highly capital intensive industry, and that is not in question. That is another way of saying that the cost of capital is the key element in the industry, not the cost of labour as such, and particularly not the cost of labour if there are no restrictive work practices in the industry, which is what the Minister has told us. I hope that so far the Minister is able to follow me and that I have not said anything which misrepresents his position, because I do not want to do that. If that is the case, and given that the real cost of capital is virtually the same-it ought to be the same-in this country as in any other, why does the industry need the tremendous amount of protection that it is presently getting? That is question No. 1. Secondly, what on earth can an authority of the kind that the Minister is proposing to set up do to remedy the problem of the comparative cost of capital if that is the problem?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not addressing my remarks to the cost of capital. I agree it is an important issue in a broader discussion, but I was talking about the use of capital equipment.
—You said there were no restrictive work practices.

—Even in the countries where the honourable senator would argue, and I would probably agree with him, that the cost of capital may be lower than in Australia, industries in those countries still want to get the best benefit in terms of labour use from that capital investment. All I am saying is that we have to do that here too.
—But you said there was no problem-there were no restrictive work practices. So why aren't we getting the best use from labour?

—I did not say that. I said that the difficulty was that in the context of the second tier negotiations a number of textile companies said that they could not see the trade-offs they could get in terms of productivity from the work force. That may be a sad observation, but the fact is that it was said.
—You mean the managers are mugs; is that the point? The managers are no good. What is the problem?
—It is very easy for Senator Stone, as an Opposition senator from Queensland, to say that the managers are mugs.
—No, I didn't say that. That was the implication of your statement.

—It is very easy for the honourable senator to say that. I am not going to say it here. I have views about deficiencies in management across a wide range of industries, but I am not going to single out this industry for such a beautifully pejorative expression as the honourable senator has just used.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Partly because we are on the air I do not want to let it lie on the record that I have said that the managers in this industry are mugs. What I did say was that the Minister's remarks could only be interpreted in that light. The Minister has now said that he does not want to say that about them at all. What he had previously said was that the managers in question had told him that there were no restrictive work practices in the businesses which they are running, because otherwise they would attempt to bring them into contention in the course of the second tier negotiations. The Minister went on to suggest that maybe that is where the problem is, that they do not know where the restrictive work practices are. The clear implication in the Minister's statement-I do not in the least want to put words in the Minister's mouth-was that the managers did not know the facts of their industry, that there were in fact restrictive work practices there that they did not know about, and that this new Authority could do something to fix it up. If I have misinterpreted the Minister I would be glad for him to set the record straight. But clearly that was the implication of what he said. If he reads the Hansard record, I am sure he will agree with me.

SPEECH.PARA: On the basis of that I want to return to my earlier point. Either there are restrictive work practices in this industry, in which case Senator Bishop was completely correct in her views, which the Minister attacked, or there are no restrictive work practices in the industry, which was my original understanding of what the Minister was saying. He now says that that is not what he was saying. If there are no restrictive work practices in the industry, presumably the only problem that the industry has is the relative cost of capital compared with the cost of capital for some competitive industry abroad.

There may be some reasons why the cost of capital in Australia is higher than the cost of capital in, say, Taiwan, if that could be used as a comparison. But there ought not to be any difference between the cost of capital in the two countries except in so far as lenders decide that there is a risk premium attaching to lending to businesses in Australia. That leads to the whole question about why people have a very bad view of this country compared to Taiwan. That would take us way outside the ambit of this Bill, and I do not propose to pursue that. However, I do observe that that also is not something which this Authority can make the slightest contribution to solving. Only this Government's or a future Government's policies can make any contribution to solving that problem. What I am saying is that the Government has to accept that either there are restrictive work practices in the industry-in which case there is a problem and the Government might be able to do something about it through the Authority, although I personally doubt it-or there are none, in which case: What is the point? The problem may be, as I said, the relevant cost of capital in other countries, about which the Authority can do nothing. In that case the extremely high levels of protection being accorded to the industry would hardly seem to be justified.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I really think some confusion has crept into the debate which I suspect may exist in Senator Stone's mind. In using the expression `work practices', one is not talking about hours of work. The question of hours of work is a relevant question in relation to the use of capital. It is not a question of work practices, it is a different thing. In responding to Senator Bishop I was talking about what are conventionally regarded as work practices in Australia, and in respect of these industries, I think there are far fewer bad work practices than there are in many other industries in this country.
—That is different from saying they don't exist, which was your first statement.

—I have not said they do not exist. I do not know whether they exist or not. But what I said earlier to the honourable senator was that, in the course of the second tier negotiations, I was informed that one of the difficulties in the textile industry was the views of the employers that they could not find adequate trade-offs for the 4 per cent wage increase. That was not true in other industries, but in this industry that was said. That was passed on to me. I do not rush around checking all of these statements and making an assessment of the IQ of particular managers for the benefit of senators in the debate on this Bill. I am sorry, but I do not have time to do all that. All I was passing on to the honourable senator is what was said to me about the second tier negotiations in the textile industry and some of the statements that were made about work practices. It is absolutely essential in an industry like this to utilise capital equipment as well as possible. That relates to the question of the spread of working hours, which is not an issue of work practices. It is a different issue altogether. Senator Stone added a codicil to his remarks by asking a question which I assume--
—That is a bad term to use in this place.

—Not entirely, Senator Watson. As a former Tasmanian textile manager, the honourable senator might regard `codicil' as a bad expression. But Senator Stone added a codicil to his remarks, which was simply to say: Why, if these problems do not exist, are the high levels of protection necessary? I regard that as a rhetorical question which will echo around this chamber and this country probably for some time to come.

—I think one feature has escaped a lot of speakers in this debate, and that is that the textile industry is still a highly labour intensive industry. While the industry is steadily moving towards greater capital intensity, relative to most other industries it is regarded as a labour intensive industry. Because of that notion, the on-costs tend to be quite significant relative to other industries, such as the aluminium industry and the like. I think the managers are quite right when they say that work practice problems essentially are not as bad across the board as they are for other industries, but it is still an industry in which there is a proliferation of unions. Wherever there is a proliferation of unions, there tend to be demarcation problems. I think the managers are quite right when they say that work practices are not a problem, because they are not a problem that they can solve. They are a problem that I think the Government, industry and the unions have to acknowledge. We have got to simplify the situation in relation to work practices. So the work practices problems that management can solve that are subject to second tier negotiations are really outside the scope of local management. Its ability to improve work practices is somewhat limited. We must acknowledge that it is still a labour intensive industry. As it moves towards restructuring, to greater capital intensity, and becomes more export oriented, it will become less dependent on tariffs.

—I am glad that Senator Watson raised that point, although it does not concern the clause that we are dealing with, because it allows me to comment that as long as the tax structure is substantially based on tax on income, of course, the cost of labour will remain high. It is something that the Government may care to consider in relation to the current debate that is emerging regarding a consumption tax and whether tax on capital and on property--
—I thought that debate was submerging today, Senator.

—It may well be. It is following a fluctuating course. I simply observe that one of the reasons for the high cost of labour is that high taxation is imposed on labour and the use of labour. I want the Minister to address a point which he has not addressed-that is, these four words, `in the public interest'. It seems to me that Senator Button has given a very unlikely explanation for the interpretation of those words.
—You move to take them out later and I will express a view about that then.
—I understood that this matter was before the Committee.
—The Committee is considering clause 45. I understand that later specific amendments will be proposed to clause 45.
—The deletion in toto is the matter that is before us.
—Clause 45 as a whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burns Sen B.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to comment on the question of demarcation disputes and to put on the record that in the second tier negotiations it was made clear that there was a problem about finding trade-offs and savings by way of work practices. A couple of years ago, during the negotiations concerning the 38-hour week, the Stubbies Clothing Co. indicated that it was so efficient that it could not make any work practice savings. The transcript will show that that was said. It is not an assumption. It is on record; it is a fact.

SPEECH.PARA: I say to Senator Watson that it is true that if there are a number of unions the opportunity for demarcation disputes exists, but if there are only one or two unions there is less opportunity for disputes. This does not automatically mean that demarcation disputes will occur. In my 30-odd years in the trade union movement I am not aware of demarcation disputes in the clothing industry. But I am aware that people who work in that industry-particularly those who have to work in their own homes for very low rates-certainly have not been responsible for any union problems that have been raised by Opposition senators, or any demarcation disputes.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to respond to Senator Burns. Whenever there is a proliferation of unions in an industry, there is an inherent opportunity to improve work practices if the number of unions is reduced. The textile union is very good as far as lack of industrial disputes is concerned. I am the first to acknowledge that. The only point that I wish to make is that when there is a proliferation of unions, the work practice situation can be improved in the long run by getting a harmonious amalgamation of unions. This will overcome built-in, inherent or structural work practice situations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —Before we vote on this clause I wish to raise two matters with the Minister. Firstly, is it intended to appoint a lawyer as the Chairman of the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority? I refer the Minister to a statement by Mr Garry Downes, QC, Chairman of the Administrative Law Committee of the Law Council of Australia. On page 4 of his opinion he said:

SPEECH.PARA: I cannot stress too strongly my view that powers as extensive as those given by Part V should generally be confined to judicial enquiries by persons with legal qualifications. Even in this modern period of enlightenment as to the laity it must still be true to say that lawyers are best able to understand and deal with legal enquiries governed by legal rules.

I think that is a very strong argument in support of my contention that part V should be deleted, unless the Minister is prepared to respond by saying that it is intended to appoint a lawyer as Chairman of this Authority.
Secondly, I point out to the Minister that on page 10 of his second reading speech-I will come back to the first sentence of it later, in relation to clause 63-he said:

I would stress that any information provided to the Authority on a confidential basis is required to be treated as such. While the Authority will be monitoring developments within the industries, it will not be intrusive-
The conduct of formal inquiries, by definition, makes it intrusive. He went on to say:

and I envisage its information requirements will most likely be satisfied by statistical collections by the Australian Bureau of Statistics and discussions and periodic surveys, similar to those previously undertaken by the TCF Advisory Committee.
Why does the Minister say that in his second reading speech when the Bill contains these powers to conduct a formal inquiry to obtain this sort of information?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —In answer to the first question, the Chairman of the Authority will certainly not be a lawyer. Senator Lewis might have some profound faith in the necessary ability, efficacy or talent of lawyers to deal with these matters, but I do not.
—Just answer the question. Don't try to be smart.
—I am not trying to be smart. Senator Lewis argued--
—The Minister is misrepresenting the question.

—Senator Stone has not been present, yet he makes interjections. He does not know what was said the other day as he was not here. The answer to the question is: No, the Chairman of the Authority will not be a lawyer. I went on to make a comment about the sorts of remarks made earlier by Senator Lewis when he said that because of the formalities a lawyer should be appointed. This indicates his profound faith in the efficacy and ability of lawyers to deal with these situations. That is a view which I do not share; that is all. We are in disagreement about it. The Chairman will not be a lawyer.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, Senator Lewis referred to comments made by the Law Council of Australia. These comments were made before the Government announced that it would introduce all the amendments that it has introduced. They have no relevance to the division or part of the Act as it will be amended, with the agreement of the industry which Senator Lewis says will be aggrieved by these provisions. Thirdly, he raised the question of whether there is some inconsistency between what I said in my second reading speech and the notion of a formal inquiry. If one does not have formal inquiries-formal in the sense that people come to the Authority, in many circumstances the Authority would ask them for information in public, and would fix days for meetings-one immediately lays the Authority open to the charge that it is doing deals with people in private. That is the worst possible thing to have. There is no inconsistency between those two things. There is no inconsistency between the passages which Senator Lewis referred to in the second reading speech that information will be treated on a confidential basis-the thing is not intended to be intrusive-and the notion expressed in the legislation of a formal inquiry. If we had said in the legislation that the Authority can obtain information and had said nothing else, everybody would have said, `Ah, ah; they will be doing deals with A, B, C, D and E in this industry'. That is the last thing we want. There is no inconsistency there. Those are the answers to the honourable senator's three questions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to rise, although I had not intended to speak again. The Minister has misrepresented me badly. He is being smart again. We were going along all right, but now he is trying to get smart. The simple truth of the matter is that I pointed out to the Minister that a Queen's Counsel-a senior silk-in Australia has said that, if we give powers as wide as we are giving in part V, we are looking at a judicial commission. We are looking at a royal commission-type inquiry when we have powers such as those contained in part V. They still exist notwithstanding the Government's amendments. Earlier, the Minister said, `If the amendments are carried'. I can assure him that if I am not successful, the amendments will be carried. Of course I will support the Government's amendments because they modify and remove parts of part V. So they will be carried if my proposals are not carried. What I point out to the Committee is that if we establish any body and give it the powers of a royal commission we create a legalistic body. My understanding, as the Minister has explained, is that it is not intended that this will be a legalistic body. Therefore, there is no need for part V. I believe that my argument is irrefutable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the leave which has been granted, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 18, subclause 45 (2), line 35, leave out `in the public interest'.

In fact the Committee has already conducted most of the debate necessary on this amendment. I merely reiterate that the Government parties-the Australian Democrats will be supporting the Government-having decided that this Authority should have the power to conduct formal inquiries and acknowledging that the inquiry shall be held in public, it seems to me to be right and proper that if the Authority wishes to hold the inquiry in private, for whatever reasons it may wish to hold that inquiry in private, it should be allowed to do so. It should not be limited only to holding the inquiry in private if it is necessary or desirable in the public interest so to do. It seems to me to be reasonable that the Authority should be able to make up its own mind. If it considers it is necessary or desirable for any reason, in effect, to hold the inquiry in private then it may do so. I say that because there have been some discussions about confidentiality and that requires me to foreshadow my concern about clause 63. Clause 63 (1) provides:

The Authority, a member of the Authority or a member of the staff of the Authority shall not supply information to a person if the supplying of the information would constitute a breach of confidence.
That clause, on its face, is fine. But then that clause is qualified by subclause (2), which states:
Subsection (1) does not apply to anything done:
(a) for the purposes of this Act; or
(b) as required or permitted by law.

We know that the Government is intending, as a result of the representations we have made previously, to debate paragraph (a) for the purposes of this Act, but that still leaves clause 63 providing that subclause (1), about confidentiality, which I have just read out, does not apply to anything done as required or permitted by law. Once this Act has been passed, then it is law. So really the Government's amendment by deleting paragraph (a) does nothing. The truth of the matter is that the confidentiality provisions of clause 63 are not worth the paper they are written on in this Bill.

In the light of that I say to the Minister that clause 45 ought to have the words `in the public interest' deleted. I might also foreshadow discussion about clause 66, which gives the Authority power to delegate all or any of its authorities under this Act to a member of the Authority or to a member of the staff of the Authority. In other words, under clause 66 the Authority might, for example, delegate to a member of the staff of the Authority the power to conduct an inquiry under clause 45. That member of the staff of the Authority might then go and hold an inquiry in public as to the activities of some person associated with the textile, clothing and footwear industries. I suggest that those are extraordinarily wide powers and that the deletion of the words `in the public interest' in subclause (2) would make some improvement to the clause.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate to the Committee that the amendment is acceptable to the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make the point, to get it on the record, that the explanation made earlier by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) that the words `in the public interest' could be interpreted as protecting the private interests of manufacturers takes no account of an emerging debate in society to the effect that copyright, patenting, those things which hitherto we have regarded as being in the private interest, are being regarded now by a substantial section of the academic community involved in this debate as being in the public interest; in other words, that there be no private interest as defined by the Minister. His explanation seems to take no account of that emerging debate in the community. I certainly could not accept the interpretation the Minister has given that the words `in the public interest' could be defined as including the private interest as the definition of that term has been understood either to. I am pleased to note that the Minister is prepared to remove those four words.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said during the second reading debate, the amendment which the Australian Democrats would like to see inserted in clause 54 is of a more general nature and relates to a great deal of legislation. There seems to be no reason why this matter should not be taken up in respect of this Bill and also dealt with as each subsequent piece of legislation comes forward. I understand from my Democrat colleagues that the Government was asked several years ago to inquire into and report back on the relationship between penalties that are expressed in both monetary and imprisonment terms. I ask the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) whether that inquiry has been conducted, what the state of the inquiry is and whether any information is available.

SPEECH.PARA: In furtherance of the amendment which the Democrats are proposing, I merely point out that the penalty of a $1,000 fine or imprisonment for 12 months bears no relationship whatsoever to each other either with respect to average wages or with respect to the wages of the person who is fined. It seems grossly unfair that penalties should be so widely separated in terms of the impact which they would have on an individual. For instance, if a person were reasonably well-heeled, the fine of $1,000 would, of course, not be particularly significant. If a person were unable to pay that fine of $1,000, the penalty of 12 months in gaol would be a very severe penalty to impose. If there is to be a reasonable relationship between these two penalties, I believe that the penalty suggested in my amendment should apply-namely, that instead of 12 months the gaol term should be something like two weeks. That period is arrived at on the basis of an average wage of roughly $20,000 a year. This would bring the two penalties into line.

During the second reading debate I said that there is evidence-and this was brought out very nicely in several Australian Broadcasting Corporation programs on imprisonment-that the earlier days of imprisonment are the most effective. It was argued that putting someone in gaol-particularly the sort of people who may get caught up in this legislation-for a short period, such as three days, and denying them their liberty, with all of the opprobrium and everything else associated with a gaol term, may, in many respects, be just as effective as keeping them in gaol for 12 months. Certainly, this would be much less expensive for the community.

During the second reading debate I also referred to the violence which is occurring in gaols now. I drew the Senate's attention to the case of the young lad who had chosen to go to gaol rather than pay parking fines and who has now finished up in hospital as essentially a human vegetable for the rest of his life. The imposition of that penalty compared with the alternative penalty of $1,000, which is relatively trivial in this day and age, seems to me to be excessive. Moreover, the penalty of $5,000 in relation to companies is really a trivial one when we consider that a 12-month penalty may be placed against an individual.

For these reasons, I commend to the Committee the amendment that the terms of the penalties be changed to bring them into line-namely, $1,000 or two weeks. I draw attention to another amendment which seeks to bring other sanctions in this Bill into similar conformity. I move:
(1) Page 21, subclause 54 (1), lines 15 and 16, leave out ``12 months'', insert ``2 weeks''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government does not accept this amendment. Similar penalties for the same class of offence have been included in this legislation on the advice of the Attorney-General's Department because they are consistent with the penalties provided in a number of other Acts-the Conciliation and Arbitration Act and the Industries Assistance Commission Act are two that come to mind-which relate to other similar authorities. I think there is virtue in consistency. These provisions refer to maximum penalties, not minimum penalties. It is open to a tribunal to impose a lesser penalty than the maximum provided for in these provisions. I would argue against Senator Coulter's amendment largely on the basis of the need to maintain consistency with other legislation for similar offences.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Coulter made a general point about the appropriateness of penalties, in terms of both monetary amounts and possible terms of imprisonment. I am not able to answer that point at the moment. The honourable senator said that he understood that some general inquiry was being undertaken into this question. I am not able to give him an answer. However, I will certainly obtain an answer for him on that general issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was prepared to be persuaded one way or the other by the response of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce on this issue but, quite frankly, I did not find his response adequate. Senator Coulter made a good point when he said that there is simply no comparison between 12 months imprisonment and a fine of $1,000. I do not think it is any answer to say, `Well, that is consistent with other legislation'. I think the Government had better get its act in order in regard to other legislation and its thinking clear in regard to future legislation that it brings before this chamber. It seems that Senator Coulter's amendment is worthy of support and the coalition parties will support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to raise the general principle of penalties. I would have thought that the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce would have been briefed with respect to the general inquiry on this matter. On my understanding, it is now almost two years since we had a debate in this chamber on this subject. I have not checked the record, but I recollect that the last time we were discussing these matters Senator Gareth Evans raised the notion of looking at penalties in general. A number of Senate committees and joint committees have pointed out in recommendations that penalties in various Acts seem to be all over the place. One committee I was on, the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform, made such an observation. We sought to have a run ourselves at rationalising those penalties.

SPEECH.PARA: In the debate I am referring to, this chamber did not press ahead with changing the Act because the Government said that it was inquiring into the whole matter and that it would be far better to leave it to that general inquiry to bring all Acts into some alignment. To suggest that this Act is being aligned with other Acts is no excuse, because the other Acts are out of kilter. Inflation has been a problem. Some Acts on the statute books impose ridiculous penalties, penalties of $5, $10 or $15. The costs of any reasonable processing of them would cost the Government four, five or six times as much as the penalty itself.

The Minister at the table, Senator Button, has not even said that the Government is looking at this matter. He does not even know what the Government is doing with regard to this matter. This chamber should no longer pass legislation with penalties that are out of kilter, that are not indexed, that do not refer to the relationship between private individuals and corporate bodies in any rational, reasonable way and in regard to which no criteria are offered as to why we should penalise people in this way. I admit that there are difficulties. The Committee of which I was a member ran into difficulties working out a comparable level between the individual and the corporate penalty. Nevertheless, we were persuaded that the Government had this matter in hand.

As the Government does not even seem to know what it is doing about this matter, we have to press ahead with changing some of these penalties to prod the Government into coming up with a rational scheme such as imposing on all new legislation new sets of penalties according to set criteria, or the other alternative that has been suggested, bringing in a penalties Act which would argue the types of criteria for federal legislation and impose set types of penalties to which all other legislation was able to refer.

I do not have any brief one way or the other. However, I believe that the Committee should press ahead with amendments from here on in to penalties in legislation until such time as the Government can come up with a rational scheme for setting out penalties in legislation. I do not want it to be taken that we do not want any penalties, or that we do not want tough penalties in appropriate cases. What we are looking for are realistic and rational penalties, penalties which have some comparability between imprisonment and penalty amounts, and between private individuals and corporate bodies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee runs the risk of not being taken seriously if we allow this sort of thing to continue. We run the risk of people saying that there is one law for the rich and one law for the poor, that those who cannot afford to pay a $1,000 fine run the risk of being in gaol for six months. One is not in gaol for much longer than that for murder these days. It is a horrendously high penalty in this instance. If six months is the appropriate penalty, the monetary penalty ought to be in the vicinity of, I would think $10,000 or more and, for a corporate offence, perhaps even higher.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Macklin has dealt with the history of the matter and I shall not go over it, but it has been a long time. The Committee has been patient. The time has come when the Committee has to say what it thinks and not just wait for something to happen. Most of us are hearing from our constituents views on the question of penalties-that in some areas they are not harsh enough and in some areas they are too harsh. It is time we responded to the sort of message we are getting from our constituents and not merely drift along any longer with the argument that one of these days the Government will consider the matter. Some of the penalties that would have been, perhaps, #500 before they became, in modern terms, $1,000 are very out of touch with the gaol sentences available to a magistrate or a judge in sentencing procedures.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the general point which has been made by Senator Macklin. Before he participated in the debate I said I would try to activate something in connection with the general issue. What I find a little unsatisfactory is the way the debate has been conducted. The object all sublime should be to make the punishment fit the crime, I agree. What one is saying to the judiciary, if one says that the maximum penalty for an offence under this section by an individual is $1,000 or two weeks in the slammer, is that this is a very trivial offence; if one considers the totality of offences punishable by imprisonment for a short term or punishable by a fine. The inadequacy of the Australian Democrats' amendment is, in my view, that they have inserted the figure two weeks instead of a month, or something like that. That is what I regret. The Democrats have given a very big signal that they regard this as a very trivial offence.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not, in my view, a trivial offence. The only person who can commit this offence is an employer. It is not a trivial offence for an employer to sack somebody because he goes along to an independent tribunal and tells his story. It goes to the heart of the employment relationship, to the heart of equity and to the heart of any notion of civil liberty in this society. People who are aggrieved by a situation, as they may legitimately be, are entitled to go and give their story, their evidence, to a tribunal about the situation in respect of which they are aggrieved without running the risk of being sacked--

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you want to change the monetary amount upwards then?

—I would be quite prepared to do that, but I come back to the original point I made. What is important is the nature of the signal one gives to the judiciary. The amount of $1,000, or two weeks, puts the offence in the class of the offence that Derryn Hinch regularly commits.
—A thousand dollars already puts it there. We are talking about an employer, not an employee.
—These are maximum penalties. The Tribunal has an option.
—But you are giving a signal-$1,000. You have just said that.

—No, we are not. Even with respect to this Parliament, the disqualification for members of parliament is not whether they have been fined for something. It is whether they have been convicted of an offence punishable by a term of imprisonment of a certain duration. That is the test, not the amount of the fine. The judicial body, whatever it is, has the discretion, in terms of the gravity of the offence, to impose a fine or a term of imprisonment. What I am concerned about in regard to Senator Coulter's amendment is that the term of imprisonment he has plucked out of the air is too low. I am not saying that the term of imprisonment proposed by the Government is correct. I am quite persuaded by some of the things that have been said. I am saying that Senator Coulter in his proposed term of imprisonment is too low. That is the reason why I have difficulty in accepting the amendment. What he has done in his subsequent amendment is to say, `The monetary penalty is twice the original amount, $2,000, so therefore the term in the slammer will be a month, instead of two weeks'. He is saying: One month in gaol equals $2,000; two weeks in gaol equals $1,000. That ignores the fact that there is judicial discretion in respect of either of those penalties-monetary or a term of imprisonment. Am I right or am I right! I think it is a matter of judgment and I happen to disagree with the judgment which is inherent in this amendment. If it were slightly more significant a term, then I think the right signal would be given to the judiciary and the Australian Democrats would not be regarded in the community as a party which considers that the sacking of a person for giving evidence to an independent tribunal is an offence which can be regarded lightly.

—Senator Button tried hard but he really did not do very well. The argument put by the Australian Democrats was clearly superior. Indeed, Senator Button left aside the fact that by putting a monetary value into the penalty clause he was sending the signal that it was a trivial matter. Senator Macklin and Senator Coulter both spoke of the need to examine other pieces of legislation instead of simply saying, as Senator Reid pointed out, that this legislation has to be brought in line with the other errors. That is not good enough. I was rather disappointed that the argument, put in counter to the persuasive argument that we have decided to support, was not a little stronger.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very briefly, I think the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce misled the Committee when he said that these were maximum penalties. The relevant clause reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Penalty:
(a) in the case of a natural person-$1,000 or imprisonment for 12 months, or both;

There is a choice to impose one penalty or the other, or both. It does not state `either $500 or a week' or something similar. The penalties are clearly spelt out. The second point I make is that Senator Button has asserted that the interval of two weeks or one month in my later amendment was chosen arbitrarily. It was not. It was chosen in relation to average weekly earnings. There is a clear correspondence between those two penalties which seems to me to be at least one basis upon which to judge the relativity of periods in gaol and monetary penalties. If it is true, as Senator Button has said, that this gives an indication to the judiciary that the penalty is too small, by the same criterion that I have used, the monetary penalty should be $20,000 or 12 months in gaol. If the Minister is prepared to raise the penalty to $20,000 I would consider it. If not, I will stick with the $1,000 or two weeks imprisonment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Page 22, subclause 58 (1), lines 20 and 21, leave out ``12 months'', insert ``1 month''.

I will not repeat the arguments which I used on the previous amendment. This amendment is simply to bring into line the monetary penalties and the terms of imprisonment on the scale using roughly $20,000 as an order of magnitude as average yearly earnings. The penalty would then be a $20,000 fine or one month in gaol, or both.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I foreshadow a Government amendment to clause 63 which is to leave out subclause (2) and substitute the following:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Subsection (1) does not apply to anything done as required or permitted by law.

The effect of this amendment will be to take out paragraph (a) of subclause (2) and rewrite, as it were, paragraph (b) of that subclause. This is a normal safeguard provision in legislation. The amendment means that the Authority may not disclose information in a way which would constitute a breach of confidence unless there is a circumstance in which there is a requirement or permission by law to do so. Provisions similar to this are inserted in many Bills. For example, there may be a royal commissions Act which would have the effect of overriding the confidence provision in clause 63 (1). There may be other pieces of legislation which relate to safety or something similar which would override the provisions of clause 63 (1). This provision is found in many Acts to avoid any inconsistencies of that kind. It is a normal piece of legal machinery which should be in this Act as it is in others.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 24, subclause 63 (2), lines 8 to 10, leave out the subclause.

I object to the way in which the Minister intends to deal with this. It seems to me that the amendment foreshadowed by the Minister should be in two parts. The first part should be that lines 8 to 10, which is subclause (2), be left out. This is identical to the amendment which I have moved. The dispute is as to the insertion, so at this stage we really ought to deal only with the first part of the Minister's amendment, which is the same as my amendment. This will now enable us to debate the whole clause.
Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move what remains relevant of Government amendment (9) which has been circulated, and what is relevant is:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 24, clause 63, insert the following subclause:
``(2) Subsection (1) does not apply to anything done as required or permitted by law.''.

I rely on the grounds which I advanced earlier, that this is a normal safeguard provision in legislation of this kind which simply means that while the Authority has a duty of confidentiality, there may be circumstances provided for by other laws such as a royal commission Act in respect of which disclosure of information would not be a breach of confidence when it was done for the purposes of that other law.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition parties oppose the proposal by the Minister. The argument that he has just put is quite meaningless. Of course what people are permitted to do by law they are permitted to do by law. The Minister does not need to say that in the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority Bill 1988 in order to legalise it. The point I tried to make to the Minister is that the original subclause (2) (a) says in effect that the confidentiality provisions do not apply to anything done for the purposes of the Act. The Minister has agreed to strike that out. But he then went on to say that the confidentiality provisions do not apply to anything done as required or permitted by law. After this Bill is passed, it will become law. So all the Minister is doing is reinserting the clause that he has agreed to delete, only it is written in a different way. That is the significance of what the Minister is saying. The result of that is to leave the confidentiality provisions, so-called, in this Bill quite meaningless so far as the industry is concerned. As a result of inserting this subclause he would be simply writing off the confidentiality provisions. It may be that the Minister can say that in practice the experience with other authorities has been that they have kept confidentiality. I acknowledge that. I am not alleging that they have not. But the Authority is not required to maintain confidentiality if this amendment is made to the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I make just two points about that. The first is that to sustain one leg of Senator Lewis's argument he would have to point to a requirement in this legislation which would involve a breaking of the confidentiality provision. Secondly, I made the general point that this sort of provision is contained in a whole lot of legislation. Senator Lewis said that it is meaningless because if there is a royal commission Act or some other Act which requires the Authority to disclose information in breach of the confidentiality provision we do not need this provision. I just say that we do need this provision because, as Senator Lewis has said in discussions on numerous other clauses, this constitutes a charter for the Authority, for the industry. The Authority should look, as far as it can, to a self-contained piece of legislation to see what its powers and obligations are. It should not be placed in the position of a royal commission or somebody saying, `Look at our Act. The Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority has to interpret our royal commission Act and then break the confidentiality provision of its own Act'.

SPEECH.PARA: This provision is about providing a code for the Authority. By implication, Senator Lewis has said that on numerous other occasions when discussing the penalty provisions and so on. The Authority has to be able to look to its own Act to see what it is entitled and empowered to do. That is why the provision is there and that is why it is in numerous other pieces of legislation which provide for the powers and obligations of particular authorities or instrumentalities. It is an absolutely innocuous provision. It was not inserted at my instigation or the instigation of my Department. It is one which the Parliamentary Counsel likes to see in all Bills of this kind simply because it provides a self-contained charter within the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the argument put forward by Senator Lewis. Senator Button's response to it is less than convincing. I point out that Senator Button at least had the decency not to argue that his amendment in any way changes the initial drafting of the Bill, because it does not. Once this Bill becomes a law of itself it is then part of the law to comply with which the Bill would permit confidentiality to be broken. His argument that there would have to be a power in the Bill which would afford a breach of confidentiality of course is only part of the case. Clause 67 empowers regulations to be made and regulations may afford just that sort of opportunity. The need for a protection of confidentiality in the Bill goes back to the arguments we had over clause 45 (2), when Senator Button accepted the amendment to take out the words `in the public interest'.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Button seems to think that because he wishes the Act to be interpreted in a particular way it will fundamentally and ultimately be interpreted in that way. For instance, when we were discussing clause 45 (2) and the meaning of `public interest' Senator Button said that he `believed' it would include the use of confidential commercial figures. He might as well have said that he `wished', he `hoped', or he `desired'.

Likewise, in clause 63, the purported confidentiality protection which is afforded is in truth meaningless because of the arguments outlined by Senator Lewis. The Minister, when making his initial remarks concerning this clause, argued that these were simply protection provisions that would be used in the sort of Bill that could be used to set up a royal commission. Yet earlier in the debate the Minister distinguished the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority from a royal commission and had gone to great pains to stress that there was no commonality between the two types of bodies. So in all honesty, the Minister ought to reconsider his position and realise that the protection which is purported to be afforded is meaningless, and allow the amendment, as previously passed-that is, the deletion of subsection (2)-to stand and that the new proposed subsection not be added to the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek guidance from the Minister. The argument seems to be tautological. Is the Minister saying that the correct interpretation is that subclause (2) (1) (b) of the original clause is retained? In other words, the clause would read:

SPEECH.PARA: Subsection (1) does not apply to anything done as required or permitted by law.

Do I understand him correctly? Is he indicating that that would mean that the confidentiality provisions, to the extent that they may be breached within this law, would not apply to itself? In other words, it would apply only to laws other than this law. That seems to me to be the nub of the argument.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —The provision is intended to apply to laws other than those contained in this Act. That is so in every Act of this kind.

—My question still stands. The answer that has been given is not good enough. It is not the intention; it is what the words actually mean that is the significant thing. Is the correct interpretation in law-and I have no legal training-of these words that these words will not apply to anything within this Act; they will apply only to other Acts?
