INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call on questions without notice I wish to make a statement on last night's industrial action by the Parliamentary Catering Service which involved a refusal to charge for food and drink provided in both the members and non-members refreshment areas. I have been advised by the Secretary of the Joint House Department that the industrial dispute in the Parliamentary Catering Service was heard in the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission yesterday afternoon. At the conclusion of the hearing the Commission strongly recommended that all industrial action cease to allow the issues in dispute to be discussed between the parties. The Federated Liquor and Allied Industries Employees Union of Australia official at the hearing undertook to put that recommendation to a meeting of its members at 10.30 a.m. today. In spite of that clear understanding, further industrial action was taken by the Parliamentary Catering Service last night. The Joint House Department has advised the union that if it lifts all bans and limitations immediately it will meet to discuss the issues in dispute next Tuesday at 10 a.m. If the union does not lift all bans immediately, the Department has advised that it will seek to re-list the matter with the Commission and seek to have stand-down provisions inserted in the award.

INTERJECT.PARA: The matter that concerns me most is the fact that there was substantial use of the members dining area and the non-members facilities. The initial estimates of losses incurred by the Parliamentary Catering Service are as follows:
Liquor in the non-members bar...$3,000
Liquor in the members bar...$1,000
Liquor in the cocktail bar...$1,200
Committees, room service and functions...$2,000
Total loss of sales...$10,000

I have also been advised this morning that some people who utilised the services last night have been advising of the amounts they owe and requesting that their accounts be charged; others are paying cash amounts. The Department is presently reconciling the exact situation and will be providing me with a report as soon as possible. I, myself, had guests last night and I have made arrangements, as well as I can, to make the payment for the amount I owe. I think all honourable senators who used the facilities have an obligation to do likewise because any unpaid bills will ultimately become a charge on the taxpayer, which would, in my view, be outrageous. There can be no compulsion in this area because of the lack of adequate records. It is really a moral decision which all honourable senators concerned have to make for themselves. The same considerations apply to those who used the non-members canteen and bar.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CHANEY
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr Deputy President, before asking a question which is on the subject that you have raised and which will be addressed to you, I seek leave to move a motion to take note of your comments. In seeking leave, I indicate that I do not intend to debate the matter beyond saying about two sentences. I do not wish to delay Question Time.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

Mr Deputy President, I note that it was part of your statement that the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission strongly recommended that all industrial action cease. I simply say that this is a further indication that there is a need for proper enforcement procedures in the conciliation and arbitration arrangements which presently do not exist. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, my question is addressed to you and relates to the matters on which you have just given us a statement, about the quite extraordinary situation which developed last night when catering staff members, as part of an industrial campaign, refused to accept payment for food and beverages in the dining rooms and bars of Parliament House. I ask: When did this situation come to the notice of the Presiding Officers? Why was a decision not taken to close the bars and dining areas immediately? Who gave the instruction that the so-called `free service' should be allowed to continue? Finally, I ask-and I think the last part of my question has been answered by you, Mr Deputy President: What action is being taken by the administration of this place to ensure that payment is made for food, drinks or other goods provided last evening without charge?

—The decision that the facilities should remain open was taken by Madam Speaker. I have spoken to her about it and it was her view that in all the circumstances it would be best if the facilities were to remain open. I was not consulted. The answer to the last part of Senator Chaney's question about what arrangements are being made to recover the amounts owing is that that will have to be looked at by the Joint House Department. I think the paucity of records will make it extremely difficult to recover the amounts concerned. It really is a matter of honour among those who incurred the debts.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr Deputy President. I thank you for your answer, but I asked you two particular questions about when this situation came to the notice of the Presiding Officers. Are you in a position to tell us when these matters came to the notice of either or both you and Madam Speaker? Have you been given any reasons as to why the decision was not taken to close the bars and dining areas?

—The matter came to my notice when I was having dinner and was informed by the waitress that I would not be charged for my dinner, which I must say outraged me. I do not know at exactly what hour the matter came to the notice of Madam Speaker, but it was certainly before the dinner break. She made the decision. I think I should leave it to her to make her own statements. It is very difficult for me to speak on her behalf. She told me, and she authorised me to tell the Senate this, that she weighed up the various factors-the industrial dispute and the necessity to provide adequate facilities for members of parliament-and decided on the balance of arguments that the facilities should remain open. I think any further statement on the matter should be made by Madam Speaker herself.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to the evasive comments regarding a consumption tax made at lunchtime yesterday by the Liberal Party candidate for Port Adelaide, Judy Fuller, on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's The World Today program. Will the Government tell the electors of Port Adelaide before the by-election tomorrow whether it will implement a consumption tax?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been asked about the evasive comments made by the Liberal candidate for Port Adelaide. I would just like to quote a couple of lines of what she said yesterday. When asked why she would not support a consumption tax, she replied:

ANSWER.PARA: I didn't say I didn't support it, I didn't say I did support it. I'm actually saying that I go with the party policy; which is that it is not in the party policy. A consumption tax is not in the party policy. As an individual my personal view, is that whatever my personal view is, if I was ever privileged enough to be a member of the Federal Parliamentary Party well then I would obviously put my personal views in the Parliamentary party room-and which determines our party policy. That's where my views belong.
I hesitated halfway through reading that quotation because I thought that I was reading the same line twice. I needed to check that I was not reading the same line twice. I repeat that I said:
As an individual my personal view, is that whatever my personal view is, if I was ever privileged enough to be a member of the Federal Parliamentary Party . . .

The word `evasive' is, I think, a bit of an understatement about the behaviour and comments of Ms Fuller, or whatever her name is. Senator Foreman also asked me whether, prior to the by-election, I could give a statement on behalf of the Government as to whether the Government will implement a consumption tax. The answer is yes, I can certainly make a definitive statement about that. Indeed, definitive statements saying that there will be no consumption tax have already been made by the Prime Minister and the Treasurer.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Finance. It follows the question already addressed to you, Mr Deputy President, by Senator Chaney regarding the events in this place last evening. As the Minister primarily responsible for controlling the spending of taxpayers' funds, does he share my disgust at the events of last night already referred to by Senator Chaney and which have been so misleadingly described as `free service' in Parliament House? Did the Minister himself, as I would expect, refuse to indulge in what I think can only be called the looter mentality operating in this place last night when some occupants of this building embarked on a food and drink binge at the expense of the Australian taxpayer? Will the Minister confirm that the cost to taxpayers, who will have to pick up the tab for the debacle which occurred within the parliamentary precincts last night, was as was stated by the Deputy President at the outset, of the order of $10,000?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I share Senator Stone's indignation, in so far as it is valid, about people who had a free binge-free to them-last night without any intention of doing anything about it. I have been asked whether I indulged. I went out to eat, which had nothing to do with what was going on in the dining room here-I was not even aware of it until long afterwards-and I had a drink in the non-members bar. I paid $20 in cash to the receipts office this morning, which more than covers anything that I drank in the non-members bar last night.
—I would hope so.

—I regard myself as having shouted a couple of other people a drink as well. I was surprised to be told by the staff in the receipts office that a number of members and senators had already either paid some money or rung up to find out how much they had to pay. It gave me a bit more faith in human nature than perhaps I might have had beforehand.

ANSWER.PARA: I wish Senator Stone would spread his indignation a bit more widely. I do not approve of members of parliament, journalists or anybody else sponging on the taxpayers through picking up free booze and free dinners in Parliament House last night, and I hope that all of those who used the service will do the right thing and pay for it. But I do not believe that the taxpayers of Queensland should be sponged on through the expenditure of $5m to provide an irrigation scheme for John Bjelke-Petersen, as the taxpayers of Queensland have been sponged upon. Such a scheme was not even on the wish list that State governments send to the Commonwealth seeking funding for water supply or irrigation schemes, but suddenly the Queensland Budget of 1985 or 1986 made provision for the building of the Mackenzie River dam. Fortuitously, just two weeks beforehand, John Bjelke-Petersen had made an application to install an 18-inch centrifugal pump in an anabranch of the river, which would have been pumped dry in about two hours, or perhaps a little longer, had there not been a permanent reservoir of water upstream from there to keep the anabranch full and to keep the water up to the 18-inch centrifugal pump. I wish Senator Stone would spread his indignation to that sort of looting of the Queensland Treasury by the former Premier's son.

On the issue before us, the union involved-I cannot remember its precise name but it is known as the Federated Liquor and Allied Industries Employees Union in some States-last night imposed what amounted to a work ban, refusing to collect money. That is a habit that the union picked up from the doctors' union in the Australian Capital Territory, which ran an industrial campaign over many months, backed up with work bans, trying to get an 85 per cent pay increase. Did we hear any indignation from Senator Stone about that? Indeed, Senator Lewis, who is not in this place today, publicly supported the doctors' union applying work bans in support of an 85 per cent pay grab.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the discredited former Treasurer?

—He was not game enough to say anything, as I recall it, which is par for the course for him. I was told last night that some of the employees of the catering service had preferred to go on strike rather than put on a work ban and were advised by their union that a work ban of this type was a better idea. I do not know why, and I am not even certain that that is true. I have not been able to verify this, but I have a clear recollection of either a regulation or something written in an Act which refers to wilful refusal by an employee of the Commonwealth to collect revenue due to the Commonwealth which imposes, if I remember correctly, a personal liability on the Commonwealth employee who wilfully refuses to collect. As I say, I state that very cautiously because I have not in the short time available been able to verify it, but I do have a recollection of there being a clause or regulation along those lines. If my recollection is correct it would seem that there might be some personal liability on the people concerned. I do not believe it would be fair to the people concerned to make them pay the $10,000, if that is the figure.
—Why not?

—Because I think the people who drank the free booze and had the free dinners ought to pay for it. That is why I think it would not be fair to impose it on the individuals. Members of the Liberal Party, of course, brag about how to get free booze, free dinners and free entertainment. All they have to do is get their firms to pay $65,000 to the Carlton Football Club and they get it all for nothing and the taxpayer foots half the bill. That is the sort of morality that applies at the highest levels of the Liberal Party. There are apparently some members of the Liberal Party in this Parliament who have a higher moral standard than that, and they have offered to pay for the food and drink they had last night for which they were not charged.
—What about the Young Liberals?

—I am coming to that. That is the second time I have been prompted about the Young Liberals. As we all know, the Young Liberals had what could euphemistically be described as a function in the Senate courtyard last night--
—For which Mr Shack paid by cheque last night.
—How did he calculate it?
—He pre-ordered the amount of grog which was to be supplied to the function. There was no more grog supplied to that function than was already paid for.

—I think I know a little bit more about it than the honourable senator; I have more up-to-date information. The Young Libs had a function which was roaring away until quite late in the night, and according to my contact in the parliamentary catering service they had about 50 cases of Fosters, although I concede it might not have all been Fosters. When I heard this I thought that the Young Libs had picked up their bad habits from the old Libs-just like the union involved had picked up its bad habits from the doctors' union in Canberra-and particularly from Mr Elliott and his ilk, and decided that they would have a free binge on the taxpayers. I have since been advised that a charge will be made for that, but it is not the custom to send out a final account until some days after such functions are held. The normal procedure is that a gross amount is invoiced out and usually some is returned. That is then credited against a gross amount and an account is finally sent out for whatever the net amount is. I understand that that will apply in the case of the Young Liberals function last night.

—Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his answer because it reveals his true colours-both of them. Will the Minister agree that in relation to those parts of his response in which he shared my sense of disgust at the events of last night, including, if I may say so, my disgust at the apparent decision of the Speaker of the House of Representatives to authorise these matters to proceed, he has indeed been operating as a Minister for Finance and in what I would call his Dr Jekyll mode? Will he also agree that in relation to the other elements of his remarks, including his totally outrageous and unrelated remarks about events in Queensland and the doctors dispute in the Australian Capital Territory, he is operating in his other colours-in his Mr Hyde mode?
—I do not think I need to add anything to what I have already said.

—I refer the Minister representing the Treasurer to the undertaking he gave on Wednesday to seek advice from the Treasurer in relation to claimed tax advantages associated with the entertainment packages being advertised to companies by the President of the Carlton Football Club. Has the Minister received any advice on this matter from the Treasurer, and will he relay that advice to the Senate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received some preliminary advice from the Treasurer, or more accurately from the Australian Taxation Office via the Treasurer. It is a two-page advice which I shall table because, in my view, it is too long to quote the whole lot. I should like to quote a few sections of it. After summarising the fringe benefits the Carlton Football Club advertised as being available to a firm which would pay $65,000, the advice goes on:

ANSWER.PARA: To my knowledge, this Office has not been asked to rule on the application of the tax law to this particular proposal. It would require a more detailed consideration than is possible from the advertisements only in order for us to reach a concluded view on the deductibility question. However, some general observations can be made.
The general observations are to the effect that it is unlikely that all or even the greater part of the $65,000 would be a permissible deduction. The advice continues:

By way of broad comparison, we were asked to rule on this question in relation to corporate boxes provided at other major sporting events. After carefully examining the nature and purpose of the facilities provided in the boxes, their cost, and the prominence of any corporate advertising associated therewith, it was concluded that the sponsorship fees relate overwhelmingly to the provision of entertainment. We determined in these cases that only 5 per cent of the sponsorship fee would be treated as deductible.

It goes on to say that in another case 10 per cent of the cost was allowed as a deduction and the rest was regarded as entertainment. If I receive any more detailed advice from the Treasurer I will make that available to the Senate as well. In view of the last paragraph I quoted, Senator Bolkus or his Department might have a look at this with a view to investigating whether the Carlton Football Club and the Liberal Party President are guilty of false advertising.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. Has the Minister or the Treasurer received any protestations from members of the Opposition, indignant or otherwise, about the matters raised in the Senate last Wednesday?

—I presume Senator McKiernan is referring to the advertisement by the Carlton Football Club. The answer is no, I do not know whether there is any indignation in the Opposition that the Liberal Party President is setting up a scheme under which, according to his claim, he and his mates can sponge on the taxpayer in order to have a free afternoon at the footie, a free lunch and free booze all afternoon as well. There may be some indignation among members of the Opposition about Mr Elliott setting up this proposal, this rort, but none of them has made it known to me.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. In view of the fact that it is 2 1/2 years since the Government received the report of the Evatt Royal Commission on the Use and Effects of Chemical Agents on Australian Personnel in Vietnam and six months since it received the report of its special consultant, Mr Bob Hogg, on the inadequacies of that Royal Commission, I ask the Minister: first, is the Government aware of the widespread disquiet among Vietnam veterans concerning the inaction of the Minister and the Government on the Hogg report and of the dissatisfaction expressed by leading international scientists whose work was quoted in the Royal Commission report; second, has the Government examined the results of the three major studies undertaken since the report of the Royal Commission on the effects of agent orange; and, third, will the Minister advise the Senate if and when Cabinet intends to consider all of these factors and come to a decision on the implementation of the recommendations of the Hogg report?

—As Senator Button advised Senator McLean on 18 February, the complaints by Swedish scientists form part of a submission to the Government by the Vietnam Veterans Association-and the Government is aware of those complaints. The Department of Veterans' Affairs has continued to monitor a number of relevant studies published since the completion of the Royal Commission. If Senator McLean would care to let the Minister know to which studies he is referring, it will be possible to check that those studies have also been considered. As Senator McLean is also aware from previous answers I have given on behalf of the Minister, Mr Humphreys, Mr Hogg was engaged as the ministerial consultant to assist in the preparation of proposals to go forward to Cabinet and the process of preparing that submission is well advanced. The Government's response to the Royal Commission report and submissions from the Vietnam Veterans Association will be announced after the submission has been considered by Cabinet.

—Has the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training been drawn to claims in the South Australian media by Mr Connolly, an Opposition frontbencher, about trends in the level of social welfare payments and unemployment in South Australia? Are these claims about the numbers of social welfare recipients under the Hawke Government correct? If not, are the claims part of a pattern of grossly inaccurate and uninformed comments about real trends in South Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of a report which quotes Mr Connolly as saying:

ANSWER.PARA: Since the Hawke Government came to power in 1983, 19 per cent of South Australians have become dependent on a pension or benefit, a substantial increase from the 15 per cent in the Fraser years.

He went on apparently to draw some causal link between unemployment and poverty. I am certainly not denying that there is some causal link, but I have checked out the figures and I am not surprised, I must say, to find out that they are quite wrong. Indeed, they are so wrong that one is entitled to believe that Mr Connolly might even have had a hand in the Liberal Party's alternative Budget last June. In June 1982, there were 1.33 million people in South Australia, of whom 244,000 were social security or benefit recipients. That is 18.3 per cent in June 1982, not 15 per cent as Mr Connolly had claimed, during the Fraser years. However, in June 1983, which, although in the period when this Government was in office, was at the point where the full effects of the disastrous Fraser-Howard recession had been felt, there were, of the 1.34 million people in South Australia, 269,000 on pensions or benefits. That is 20 per cent. So when the full effect of the Fraser-Howard recession-and perhaps Senator Stone might like to take some of the credit as well-had worked its way through South Australia, 20 per cent of the people were on unemployment benefits. That was up 1.7 per cent on what it had been one year before. The reason for that increase was the rocketing unemployment of late 1982 and early 1983.

TALK.START.PARA: —Induced by Mr Kelty and Mr Crean.

—I suggest to Senator Stone that it was induced by the abdication of responsibility by the Fraser-Howard Government in May 1981 when the then Prime Minister thought it was more important to duck off to London for the royal wedding than it was to try to get any sort of a wages policy. He then said-and this advice may have come from Senator Stone-`Let the market-place determine the outcome'. Well, the market-place did determine the outcome. There was a 13 per cent wages explosion in 1981 and a 14 per cent explosion in 1982. But the most recent figures, those for June 1987, showed there were 1.39 million people in South Australia and 270,000 on benefits-that is 19.4 per cent. That is certainly a higher figure than anybody would like to see but it is a significant reduction on the 20 per cent figure that applied four years before when the full effect of the Fraser-Howard recession had worked its way through. It appears that Mr Connolly is a bit like Senator Vanstone: he has allowed his name to be used without checking the facts, or he is incompetent and has made the error himself, or he has deliberately given false information to the Press.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. My question also concerns the rip-off of the Australian taxpayer resulting from last night's industrial action by catering staff members. Given that this incident is but the latest, and certainly the most outrageous, of recent times, what action will the Minister for Industrial Relations take to ensure that the union concerned does not continue its reprehensible behaviour? Has he noted the comment of his colleague, Mr George Gear, chairman of the so-called social national price watch committee, who is reported in today's Age as saying he was `supporting the workers' by drinking for free at the non-members bar? Will the Minister dissociate himself and the Government from the totally irresponsible attitude adopted by the honourable member for Canning, who so sanctimoniously rails against alleged overcharging by doctors and others, yet who last night gleefully helped himself at the expense of those for whom he claims to be concerned?

—Mr Deputy President, in so far as the latest outrage-as you so described the events last night-is concerned a number of questions have been directed both to you and to Senator Walsh about that matter, and I have nothing to add to what has been said. I have not seen the comments of Mr George Gear. I do not know whether he said he was supporting the workers or supporting the bar. They are different concepts altogether. But the simple point which the honourable senator is trying to make is made by singling out an Australian Labor Party member of parliament and accusing him of outrageous behaviour, on the basis of some statement which he is alleged to have made. By asking that question he psychs up morally self-righteous people like Senator Stone, who has been riding his white charger throughout Question Time. He has a total monopoly on morality in these matters and suggests that nobody else has any. We can play this game in the Parliament. I could dig up today a Liberal Party senator who was found lying on the lawns last night, and ask whether he paid for his drinks. But I am not going to do that, because there is absolutely no point in it except in the minds of people who can see through a keyhole with both eyes. I am not one of those people. There are a few here on the other side of the House.

—I take a point of order, Mr Deputy President. The honourable senator has alluded to the fact that there was a male Liberal senator on the lawns outside Parliament House. I ask that he withdraw that statement unless he has evidence that a Liberal senator was lying on the lawns outside Parliament House.
—There is no point of order. That is not a personal reflection on an individual.

—Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. I was not aware that the Minister had concluded his answer. I thought that he was interrupted by a point of order. The central aspect of the question I asked related to the industrial relations aspects of this issue. I ask the Minister again what action the Minister for Industrial Relations proposes to take to ensure that the union does not continue its reprehensible behaviour of which last night was simply the most recent example?

—Perhaps the honourable senator lives in some sort of sheltered world and now that there is an industrial dispute in the parliamentary arena it has been drawn to his attention that industrial disputes take place in various places throughout Australia at various times. There just happens to have been one here last night and I gather that the honourable senator found that particularly exciting and reprehensible. The Minister for Industrial Relations is not in the business of sticking his beak into every industrial dispute that takes place, and he should not be--
—This is in the Parliament.

—That is right. It is in the Parliament and the honourable senator, the customer, is a very important person. It is not like ordinary people in the community who suffer from industrial disputes. She is different and that is what she is concerned about and that is the point of Senator Chapman's question also.
—I was referring to the fact that yesterday's occurrences were nothing more than a taxpayers' rip-off.
—Order! That is not a point of order.

—It is not the function of the Minister for Industrial Relations to intervene in every industrial dispute that takes place; it is a matter between the parties. Here there is an employer party just as there is an employee party, just as there are in other circumstances. It is certainly not the function of the Minister for Industrial Relations to go around--
—We are asking what the employer is doing.

—I am dealing with Senator Chapman's question at the moment, not Senator Stone's question. If he wants to ask me a question about what the employer is doing he should not direct it to me because I have nothing to do with that. I am representing the Minister for Industrial Relations in answering this question and, as I have said, it is not his function to go around involving himself with the details of every industrial dispute which takes place in this country. I must confess that we have done a little more than Opposition senators ever did in government with a great deal of success, which has brought industrial disputation in this country to a level of less than 50 per cent than it was under the Liberal Government. There has been some success in that. But that is not the function of the Minister for Industrial Relations and I will not even pass the question on to him.

—Is the Minister representing the Treasurer aware of the Institute of Public Affairs (IPA) award for the most restrained and responsible Budget for State governments? Did the most recent award go to Queensland and was it judged by the Director of the IPA's State Policy Unit, Mr Les McCarrey? Does the Government place particular value on the analysis provided in judging these awards? Is the Minister aware of Mr McCarrey's particular qualifications for judging the awards?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable senator asked four questions. The answer to the first two questions is yes; Mr McCarrey was the judge and the award was given to Queensland. I was asked what value the Government places on Mr McCarrey's analysis. The answer would have to be not very much at all and there are a number of reasons for that. One reason is that, after the 1986 Budget, Mr McCarrey published an article in which he forecast that the Budget deficit would blow out in 1987; that that was built into the system; that it would probably blow out in 1986; and that the 1986 Budget was basically phoney anyway. Of course, that somewhat tarnished whatever reputation he may have had before.

ANSWER.PARA: But it goes back very much further than that. Mr McCarrey is, by no stretch of the imagination, an analytical or objective observer. Some years ago, evidence was given to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations by a Sydney underwriter and stockbroker which showed that State electricity commissions (SECs) in general were in a perilous financial position and that the Western Australian SEC was in a particularly perilous financial position. I recall asking the witness whether a particular table showed that the Western Australian SEC was borrowing money to pay interest on money previously borrowed without adequately disclosing that fact. The answer to that question essentially was yes, but Senator Withers quipped in with one of his pithy comments that that was the sort of thing people got locked up for if they did it in the private sector.

Eventually, I put out a Press statement saying that, if the Western Australian SEC were a private company it would be placed in receivership and its directors would be put in gaol which produced a few threatening letters from some incompetent lawyer that the then President of the Liberal Party, Mr Warner, presided over at the time. It took three letters before he could even send me the Press clippings of where this alleged defamation took place. I eventually ignored them when he sent them to me and I have heard nothing from him since, nor do I expect to.

This was published in Western Australia and the SEC got a bit annoyed. Senator Stone might be interested to hear that Mr McCarrey, who was then the Under Treasurer in Western Australia, rang the stockbroker and said, `You will recant that statement or there will be no more business for your firm from the Western Australian Government'. In other words, this objective analyst was doing Charlie Court's dirty political hatchet work.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is outrageous defamation.

—It is outrageous that he did it; I absolutely agree. I do not believe that Senator Stone would ever have done anything like that when he was Secretary to the Commonwealth Treasury. But that is the sort of background Mr McCarrey has. Mr McCarrey is a right wing ideologue who is a retired former political hatchet man for Charlie Court.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. What is the Government's attitude to the reported massive chemical weapons attack on the town of Halabja in the course of the continuing war between Iraq and Iran, as television news broadcasts revealed yesterday?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government condemns absolutely and in the strongest possible terms the use of chemical weapons against civilians in the town of Halabja. It is horrifying that thousands of people may have died in these attacks. The use of chemical weapons in the Gulf war was confirmed by three United Nations investigations, in 1984, 1985 and 1987, in which an Australian scientist participated. The latest reports strongly suggest that this has been the worst single incident of chemical warfare since World War I. The extent of the casualties, and the fact that they are unprotected civilians, make the accounts particularly shocking.

ANSWER.PARA: Australia has repeatedly condemned the use of chemical weapons and stated unequivocally that their use cannot be justified in any circumstances. We share the international community's concern that violations of the 1925 Geneva Protocol constitute a very serious erosion of international norms. The latest reports strengthen Australia's resolve to continue its efforts to achieve a comprehensive international convention banning the development, production, acquisition, stockpiling, transfer and use of chemical weapons. Australia has been playing a very positive and active role in the efforts to achieve a chemical weapons convention in the Conference on Disarmament in Geneva.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Home Affairs. I refer him to Research Report No. 2 of 1988, released recently by the Australian Electoral Commission, and entitled 1984 Redistribution, Forward Projections of Enrolments Report. I ask the Minister whether he is aware of the statement on page 3 which states:

QUESTION.PARA: In so far as any `actual' enrolment at any moment of time is affected by on-going activities in the roll maintenance process, a degree of rubberiness in that figure must be expected. Thus December (1987) enrolments included a number of entries identified for deletion under the objection process following the 1987 general election, but not sufficiently progressed to be removed. So, in Victoria, the State's total enrolment was about to be reduced by approximately 60,000 . . .

Does this mean that 60,000 people in Victoria, that is, 2.2 per cent of the total voting population in that State, who voted in the July 1987 election either should not have voted at all or voted in the wrong electoral division? If it does not mean that, what does it mean? In which electorates did this occur, and what was the proportional magnitude of this factor in each of those electorates? What are the corresponding figures for other States and electoral divisions within those States? Finally, if the Minister still supports the Australian Electoral Commissioner's claims that no Senate or House of Representatives seat was in doubt as a result of administrative errors during the 1987 election, errors which the Commissioner described as major but which the Minister chose to describe as possible minor inadequacies at a local level, does he extend this support to include other factors that may have influenced the results, including multiple and phantom voting practices?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Short has asked about ten to twelve questions. I am conscious that we have to finish by one o'clock, so I might just go to the broad aspects rather than the absolute specifics. The process of habitation reviews being under way in the period 1986-87 means that every household in one way or another is canvassed to see whether the roll is in fact accurate. Quite often, what occurs in terms of enrolment is that when people move from one electorate to another they tend to be placed on the role in their new electorate before they are taken off the roll in their old electorate. In some cases there is that duplication. There is no evidence, however, that any of those people vote in both electorates. Usually, if they have made the conscious effort to enrol in a new electorate-or their names are placed on the roll in their new electorate via the habitation review, which throws up many of these problems-there is, and always has been, a lag time in their names being taken off the roll in their old electorate. Before anyone suggests that this is something new, I say that this is somethng that has happened virtually since Federation.

ANSWER.PARA: I sometimes become a little irritated by the criticisms from those opposite of the electoral process-which, after all is, and always has been, user friendly-which suggest that suddenly something has dramatically changed in that regard. Senator Short tried to link the question of enrolment, the up-to-dateness of the rolls, and whether the result of any election might be put in doubt because of this, with those administrative errors in the statistics of the election. Of course, there is no correlation with that. It is recognised in the Commonwealth Electoral Act-for those in New South Wales and Victoria who may take an interest in this matter, it is recognised in the New South Wales and Victorian electoral Acts-that the correctness of the roll cannot be a factor in challenging an election result.

I, as Minister, and my predecessors in this role, can never absolutely guarantee that every roll is accurate at one time. We are talking about nine million names on a roll. It is a fairly staggering thing to keep up to date. We are trying to keep that roll as up to date as possible. At the moment that process is assisted by habitation reviews every two years. We are trying to negotiate with the States to pick up part of the cost so that we can embark on habitation reviews every year.

We are looking at computerisation of the rolls. When I say computerisation of the rolls, of course the names of electors are on computer tapes. I am referring to a direct process from divisional returning officers to the central computer so that the rolls are constantly updated. Senator Short would realise from his knowledge of this area that a lot of that is tied up with the regionalisation proposals that have not progressed. As a throw-away line he referred to false enrolments, phantom voters and double voters. Quite frankly, in the time available to me, I cannot address those matters. But I will be very happy to do so at another time because I think that a lot of myths are put around.

I must criticise the Press-I do not often do it-for its gullibility in quite often running stories unchecked. This is especially true of talk-back radio people in Sydney who have quite often run stories in the last eight months about vulnerability, crooked elections, or whatever. When I write to these people and say, `That was an interesting view, please put forward one piece of evidence that substantiates that view', I never get a response. Our electoral system could not be described as not being vulnerable to attack. It is user friendly. There is no major evidence at this stage that it has been attacked. If it does become vulnerable and people-not so much from organised political parties but people with anarchistic views-decide to attack it, the remedies that we will need to put in to protect the system are fairly draconian.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has great gaping loopholes.

—Senator Bishop says that it has gaping loopholes. It had the same loopholes when the Opposition was in government that it has now that we are in government, but we now have a far more accountable system. These days we do not just sit back and say, `We are not going to worry about this. We are not going to run statistical checks or constant habitation reviews'. Some of the problems that may have existed from 1901 are being exposed a little more because of the rigorous examination methods. I see that Senator Short wishes to ask a supplementary question.
—I want an answer to the first question: Does this mean that 60,000 people in Victoria voted who should not have voted?

—No, it does not mean that. There is no evidence of it. I explained that there is a lag time in taking people off the roll; not the same lag time as putting people on the roll. It existed in 1987; it existed in 1977; and it existed in 1957.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —The Deputy President has received a letter from Senator Messner proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the State for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The widespread alarm in the community concerning the Government's threat to tax people's superannuation.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Hawke Labor Government has lost its direction. In no area of public policy has it lost it more than in that of retirement income security for Australians. Since the day of its first election in 1983, it has broken promise after solemn promise on superannuation to the Australian people. First, it introduced a lump sum superannuation tax. Then it wiped out access to the pension for people over 70 years. Finally, it introduced the infamous assets test with its hidden traps and anomalies for the unwary. We are not just talking here about the aged in the community. It is important to recognise that we are now faced with another terror for the whole community-tax is to be applied to superannuation funds so that the benefits which people expected to collect at the end of their working lives will have been so substantially reduced that their hopes of financial independence will be dashed on the rocks of Paul Keating's twisted view of political economics.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us just see what undertakings have been given by this Government in recent times on the question of taxation on superannuation. Mr Hawke in recent days has said, `The Government will not consider changes which could impact adversely on already accrued superannuation'. Secondly, he said, `The Government will not make any changes which would stop people taking lump sum superannuation benefits'. Thirdly, he said, `Superannuation will continue to be treated on a concessional basis'. All these things are chock full of weasel words. They provide opportunities for the Government to hedge on any of the decisions that it finally takes in May. To say that none of the measures that will be taken are retrospective is ridiculous. They will reduce the potential for people to accumulate superannuation over the years of their working lives. Mr Hawke has not said that existing 100 per cent lump sums may be affected or that taxing lump sums in a manner which makes it more attractive to pensioners will not occur. If there is going to be a concessional basis for taxation of superannuation, what degree of concession will be applied? These matters are still very much in the air and in the minds of the Australian people at present. They are worrying them silly. We could see an increase in the lump sum superannuation tax; we could see a tax being applied on the income of superannuation funds; and we could see a reduction in the tax concessions granted not only to employer contributions, but also to the self-employed. The introduction of a levy, such as the Medicare levy, could be applied as well. Worst of all, especially for the business community, we may see a fringe benefits tax being introduced on contributions to superannuation funds.

Let us just consider what kind of people are being affected by these proposed actions. If young people just entering the work force see that these things are likely to come into force, they will say, `Why bother to join superannuation funds? By the time I reach retirement the Government will have cut my entitlement by as much as a third, a half, or more. I won't be able to live off the income anyway. What is the point in struggling to put money away today when I can better use it for my own benefit right now?'.

The family situation is important. Families moving through the most expensive time of their lives with children to educate and mortgages to pay will be tempted to drop out of superannuation funds when they see the Government taking so much of their savings. Many people who have not previously been in superannuation are now being enrolled in current union-based superannuation schemes. We have always supported schemes of that kind where they are properly and independently managed. Those funds, while not complete and absolute in their structure, will provide some capital for retiring workers. But having watched the progress of this trend to union superannuation schemes, the Government now eyes it off and sees it as a lucrative source of extra revenue. The Government is now going to impose penalty taxes on superannuation funds. Eric Risstrom, the Secretary of the Australian Taxpayers Association, says that that rate of tax could be as high as 50 per cent on the income of those union-based superannuation funds. It is almost as though the Government has deliberately set up a milking cow by encouraging union-based superannuation and now proposes to start the milking. In other words, Mr Keating has established a new tax base for the Government to milk. This is despite Mr Keating's speech to the Life Insurance Federation of Australia last year when he said:
I hardly need remind you that such a tax would significantly reduce the level of retirement benefits paid to fund members.

It would therefore diminish the net value of employee and employer contributions and would inevitably lead to an increase in wage costs as the superannuation benefit losses were made up `in the field'.
That came from the Treasurer.

TALK.START.PARA: —He really said that?

—Yes, he really said that. Those words indicate that, if the Government is to take the action that is now contemplated, it is going to run directly in opposition to its stated policies on wages and incomes in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: The confusion of this Government grows. Who loses if these taxes are to be imposed? Certainly not the big companies because they have paid their contributions to the funds anyway. Certainly not the Government because it is going to get extra revenue out of all this. It is the ordinary worker who is going to cop it in the neck. He is the one who is going to miss out on the extra payments. He will find that his benefit, when he comes to retire, is reduced by as much as a third or a half of the total amount he expects. He is the one who is going to miss out, and it is this Government that is going to bring this about.

Yet the Government sits on its hands and watches Mick Young take his full superannuation, as well as his $3,000 a week job with Qantas Airways Ltd, even though it has legislated to provide that such parliamentary pensions could be reduced by income from statutory authorities such as Qantas. The Government has deliberately not acted to apply the provisions of the law when these are available to it. As Senator Newman said here yesterday, even Mr Gough Whitlam voluntarily gave up part of his pension when he took a government job in Paris. Minister Button thought that such a move would not be intelligent. This Government is peopled by a Ministry which has lost touch with the real world where people are battling to exist.

Mr Howe, the Minister for social insecurity, is more concerned with his prospects of being the next Deputy Leader of the Australian Labor Party when Hawke and Bowen go at the end of the year than with the interests of the less well off. Let us see what Mr Howe has been saying in recent times about superannuation. Mr Howe confirmed a few weeks ago that an income tax on superannuation fund income is inevitable. He attacked superannuation contributors and the managers of superannuation funds. Of course, by implication, he attacked all of those thousands of agents who work in the field for superannuation funds and distribute advice to people for the investment of their funds. By implication he has called those people deliberate avoiders of taxation. In other words, he is saying to those three million Australians who contribute to superannuation funds, `You are all a bunch of tax cheats'. That is what this Government thinks of people who are trying to provide for their own independence and security in retirement.

Mr Paul Keating, the Minister for economic tautology, is getting so impatient for the top job that he has given the ultimatum to Bob Hawke to leave by the end of the year. Hawke said that if the Party wants him to go, he will. Keating and Howe are left to make up their minds what they will do. It is obvious what that will be-one will go for the leadership and the other the deputy leadership. The Centre Left, as usual, cannot make up its mind who should replace either of them. It looks as though the Right is so disgusted with Hawke that it wants to bring Barrie Unsworth into Federal politics to offer some kind of alternative.

Taxes on superannuation are on the Australian Labor Party's agenda for May. A report that came through the news service yesterday indicated that Mr Keating wants to reduce taxes on big companies and, to achieve that, he wants to be able to tax superannuation funds. Obviously, the only people who are going to miss out here-and I repeat this-are the little people who are members of superannuation funds who will receive less as a result of those taxes being applied. This Government will see to it that big business benefits by reduced company rates of tax while the little people receive lower superannuation payouts.
Even that proposition is subject to a great deal of challenge. An article in today's Australian by Laura Tingle headed `Super levy ``could not fund tax cuts'' ', states:

A submission to the Treasury from stockbroker McIntosh Hamson Hoare Govett Ltd argues that it would be extremely unlikely the Government would be able to raise or offset the $3.5 billion that the Treasury estimates present tax concessions cost revenue last financial year.

Even that stratagem, if the Government is contemplating it, will not work, according to a firm of experts directly interested in the field. No doubt the Government would argue that it cannot afford the $3.5 billion worth of tax that it claims to lose every year through superannuation. The Government has always failed to analyse that figure, which has almost been accepted generally in the community as fact. It is wrong to accept the figure as it is because it fails to take account of revenue collected on income generated from superannuation investments. It also fails to take account of savings from superannuation from reduced pensions paid when income is earned from the investment of superannuation moneys.

So what is the case for superannuation? We know that now and in the future, particularly in the next century, the population of Australia will age considerably, which will automatically lead to increased expenditure, whether of a private or a public kind, on age and service pensions and other income for people in that category. As an example, if pensions per head of population remained constant in real terms over that period, the cost of social security pensions for each member of the working population would increase by around 1.2 per cent per year in real terms, or 60 per cent over the period to 2025. If, however, the real value of pensions were to increase broadly in line with increases in labour productivity and wage rates, the share of pension outlays expressed in terms of gross domestic product would rise from 2.8 per cent, or $5.8 billion, which it was in 1985, to 4.5 per cent or $13.9 billion in 2025.

This is a growing and intolerable burden on the taxpayers, which leads us to the conclusion that the encouragement of self-provision for retirement should be the objective of all governments. The long term objective must be to encourage the entire work force to contribute, preferably on a regular basis, to their own retirement income, whether through superannuation, specifically identified savings, or other means. With an ageing population and an unsatisfactory replacement level, people should be encouraged to make a substantial contribution towards their own retirement incomes so as to reduce the pressure on the tax system to finance higher levels of pension for greater and greater numbers of recipients in the future.

Surely that objective stands unchallengeable. The Government should stop peddling this misleading stuff about the cost to the taxpayer of superannuation. It knows that it is wrong. It should admit that it is wrong, and immediately turn 180 degrees and start to encourage self-provision through superannuation, rather than seeking to impose further taxes on superannuation, as proposed in the May statement.

We ought to contemplate why the Government wants to do this type of thing. Let us think through the cynical political mask for a moment. We realise that it is because the Government thinks that it is politically less difficult to take away from people a chunk of their superannuation now by way of tax rather than to tax other things in the community, which people will feel in their pockets today. This is because people will not realise just how much this tax has cost them until they come to retire-some years in the future. The extra 50 per cent of their superannuation money that they expected just will not be there when they retire. So it is the least damaging political fallout that Labor is on about with these proposals. Too bad about its effects on the future living standards of the people. Too bad about the present living standards of the people, if that point needs to be made. This means that there is no hope for the future because the Government is attacking future living standards, as well as present ones.

I refer to the effect that this will have on people who have to retire early because of the conditions of their work-people in the armed forces in particular. The people who are least informed will suffer as a result of these taxes. They are the ones who are struggling to build up some little stock of capital for the future. They will be disillusioned. About a month ago the Sydney Morning Herald ran an editorial which summed up the situation very well. It said:

The superannuation debate is far too important to be hidden away in Canberra's committees. The long-term implications are far too significant for all Australians to be decided without debate. It's about time the Government came clean with a Green Paper to stimulate discussion and to calm the fears which could arise in the minds of thousands of Australians who are saving and investing for their retirement.

The people of whom that editorial speaks are concerned. They are concerned not only about the future but also about the immediate future and what will happen to their savings. The future of those people will disappear into some black hole of higher taxes. We recall the Government's campaign in recent days to tell us that taxes are somehow good for us.

However, tomorrow the people have an opportunity to tell Mr Keating and Mr Hawke what they think about this because there is a by-election in Port Adelaide. This is a wonderful opportunity for ordinary people to enter the debate which is spoken of in the Sydney Morning Herald in the most effective way. They have an unparalleled chance to let the Government feel their displeasure at the taxes that are being proposed. They can let the Government know right where it hurts most-right in the ballot box.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Finance)

TALK.START.PARA: —This little exercise is a stunt designed to distract attention from the fact that the Liberal Party will introduce a consumption tax if it ever gets into government. We know that this matter will be discussed at the Liberal Party's federal council meeting-it was dragged out of John Howard yesterday like a rotting molar. John Elliott, to whom all Australians owe a considerable debt in some respects because he keeps blowing the whistle on what is really on the Liberal Party agenda, starts talking about the absolute necessity of a consumption tax every time he gets a microphone thrust in front of him. Naturally that annoys Mr Howard because he would rather it not be known that the Liberal Party plans to introduce a consumption tax. This exercise this afternoon is just a continuation of that attempt to throw up a smokescreen, to divert attention not only from the fact that the Liberal Party intends to introduce a consumption tax but also from the fact that the President of the Liberal Party wants the Liberal Party Leader's job. SPEECH.PARA: Senator Messner spoke about parliamentary superannuation and I am very glad he did because it gives me the opportunity to let the world know of the parliamentary superannuation arrangements which applied when this Government came into office. Firstly, 100 per cent commutation was allowed. There was no tax on that lump sum payment other than 5 per cent of it being subject to normal income tax. So a maximum of 3 per cent could have been paid on the totally commuted pensions that a number of people took at that time. Fraser, Anthony, Lynch-there is a whole string of them-all ran off with more than half a million dollars and paid 3 per cent tax on the amount.

If they then croaked, a reversionary benefit of five-sixths of the pension entitlement was available, notwithstanding the fact that the pension itself had been commuted to a lump sum, by a factor of ten. Not only was there a half a million dollars plus lump sum there for the taking, with only 3 per cent tax on it, after the lump sum had been taken, but if the retired politician croaked and had a spouse the spouse also picked up 84 per cent of the pension entitlement that had already been commuted. When I tell people that story they often think I have got the facts a bit confused or they have misunderstood me. They have not; that was the system which applied when this Government took office.

There has been a clean-up since then. Firstly, there is a meaningful tax on lump sums. Secondly, only half of the pension entitlement can be commuted. Thirdly, the double dip whereby a reversionary benefit of 84 per cent of the original pension could come back to the spouse of a deceased retired politician has been wiped out as well. No wonder Senator Messner is annoyed. We cleaned up that rort that he had set up for himself and his mates, that Fraser and Howard had set up for themselves, that Fraser himself took advantage of, along with Anthony, Nixon and Lynch--

TALK.START.PARA: —With the recent release of the Economic Planning Advisory Council report entitled Economic Effects of an Aging Population, and with ongoing rumours of further changes to superannuation likely to appear in the May economic statement, I suppose it is understandable that the issue of superannuation has become a central part of the current economic and political debate. So I welcomed the information this morning that Senator Messner was going to raise this as a matter of public importance this afternoon. I had hoped, however, that the debate would rise to a somewhat higher level than it has, with the diatribe of the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) being absolutely no help whatsoever, enlightening nobody, instructing nobody and barely answering the elements that Senator Messner raised in his matter of public importance-namely, the widespread alarm in the community concerning the Government's threat to tax people's superannuation. Mind you, I would have to say that Senator Messner's contribution, although less hysterical and less abusive than the Minister's, was not a great deal more helpful since he seemed to be under the misapprehension that ordinary workers have reasonable access to superannuation and that ordinary workers are the ones at risk from whatever changes the Government may make to superannuation.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Messner finished his contribution by drawing the attention of the electors of Port Adelaide to what is likely to happen to them in the May economic statement. I would not have thought that there were too many electors in the Port Adelaide district fortunate enough to be in receipt of superannuation or in the sort of job likely to lead them to large lump sum payouts or significant superannuation benefits of any sort. Even if there were, it is also worthwhile that the electors of Port Adelaide realise that the last time the Hawke Labor Government changed the superannuation scheme, it did so with the support of the Liberal-National Party Opposition. It argued that the legislation was a Budget Bill and therefore the Opposition was not in a position even to support an Australian Democrats amendment that would have allowed recipients of small lump sum superannuation payments to be more or less cushioned against the effect of the new tax.

Probably what is more important to the electors of Port Adelaide-and I do not consider it highly likely that any of them are listening to today's debate or, if they started, that they have got this far-is that they should remember that it was with the full support of the Liberal- National Party senators that a number of other Labor Government initiatives were effected, initiatives that are far more likely to have an impact on some of the low income families in the Port Adelaide area. These issues include the delay two Christmases ago of consumer price index increases to pensioners and beneficiaries, the removal of Austudy grants to 15-year-olds in low income families, and the 1981 attempt by the Liberal-National Party Government to impose a sales tax on food, clothing and home building materials. These are all things which would have had a dramatic effect on low income families and which we were able to prevent.

The fact remains that, for a number of reasons, superannuation is a problem area. First, Australia has an ageing population. There is an increasing and, I suggest, unjustified criticism of our welfare bill from some quarters. Business and industry are anxious to encourage the Government to cut back on our welfare payments because they argue that the payments are a drain on the economy. I suggest that these people remember that people have contributed through the tax system towards their pension and benefits post-retirement. That is not as easy to see as it used to be pre-1950, when the Menzies Government made a significant change to what was then the Income Tax and Social Services Contribution Assessment Bill and introduced a single levy rather than the double levy, with the single levy to be substituted for the former two separate levies which, as Mr Fadden said in his second reading speech:

. . . will be known as `income tax on social services contribution'. This title will serve as a constant reminder to taxpayers that a substantial proportion of their payments will be devoted to Commonwealth social services. Provision will be made in a separate bill for special appropriations from the single levy, to ensure that the element of social services contribution in each person's payment shall be appropriated to the National Welfare Fund, and that that fund will have an assured income to meet its purposes.

I remind the Senate, if it needs reminding, that the national welfare fund was dispensed with a couple of years ago and we have now no easy way of reminding ourselves that through the tax system we are contributing not only by way of an income tax levy but also to the social services contribution system in particular. So to argue that our ageing population is an unnecessary drain on the welfare budget and one which has not been contributed to in any way is a fallacy.

The second reason that superannuation remains a problem is that the cost to revenue of superannuation concessions appears to be a genuine drain in the current economic circumstances and is likely to be a bigger revenue problem in the future. In 1986-87 Treasury estimated that superannuation tax concessions cost revenue $3.74 billion. That same year age pensions and allowances cost revenue $6.25 billion, and that figure is estimated to rise to almost $7 billion in 1987-88. But I repeat that a significant proportion of that has already come from contributions through the taxation system.

As long as many Australians are still excluded from superannuation, or get very little benefit from it, while a few relatively better off Australians get massive taxpayer subsidised benefits, superannuation funds will remain a prime target for a government which believes it needs more revenue now in order to meet business demands for a surplus, or which wants to introduce greater equity into the distribution of the superannuation concessions. Lump sum superannuation tax concessions are a classic regressive tax benefit, putting the largest benefit in the pockets of the highest income earners. I refer any honourable senator who is interested in this matter to the Australian Society of October last year, and to the very excellent article by a lecturer at Monash University, Rick Krever, entitled `Super: the upside-down subsidy'. That should get a few people's priorities straight. In fact, every dollar that the Government pays to the well off through tax concessions in the superannuation system is a dollar that it does not have to fund age pensions, or to reduce tax rates, or whatever else it may have on its agenda in order to introduce some sort of equity into the system.

We have then three problems: firstly, the ageing population; secondly, the cost to revenue of superannuation concessions; and the third problem is that the coverage of occupational superannuation still leaves many groups disadvantaged despite the recent moves to increase coverage via the productivity increase. Perhaps Senator Messner will be interested in some of the statistics that relate to coverage of superannuation, that relate to who benefits and who benefits most, in particular, through the superannuation scheme.

TALK.START.PARA: —But it is growing, is it not?

—I acknowledge that. One of the benefits of recent legislation is that women are now no longer exempt, as they used to be. The superannuation funds are no longer excluded from conforming to the sex discrimination legislation. But it will be a lot longer than most of us have around this place before women are treated as equitably as they should have been.

SPEECH.PARA: In August 1986 it was estimated that 39.4 per cent of employees were members of a superannuation or retirement benefits scheme which was arranged or provided by their current employer. A further 7.9 per cent were estimated to be covered by schemes not provided or arranged by their employers. All in all, a total of 47.3 per cent of employees were covered by superannuation schemes-less than half the work force. The incidence of employees covered by current employer arranged superannuation varies significantly according to a number of factors. These include: gender, full time or part time status, occupation, whether the employee is in the public or the private sector, the industry that is employing that individual, the age of the individual, and the weekly earnings of that employee. For example, 49.2 per cent of all males are covered in comparison to slightly over a quarter of all women in the work force.

As far as full time and part time status is concerned, only 7 per cent of part time employees were covered compared with almost 47 per cent of full time employees. Across occupational groups, coverage by current employer arranged superannuation for all employees varied markedly-16.8 per cent of sales people were covered compared with almost 60 per cent of managers and administrators. So we are looking increasingly at a situation where selected and selective groups are covered and other significant proportions of the work force are omitted. As far as industry is concerned, there were large variations ranging from a very low 11.2 per cent of employees in the recreation, personal and other services industry groups, to 85.4 per cent in the communications industry. The first group, needless to say, is very largely female dominated.

Despite Senator Messner's comments about the problem facing young people entering the work force if the Government should change the system, there is very little participation by young people under the current scheme. Employees in younger age groups tend to have very low coverage; something like 10 per cent of the 15- to 19-year olds, and a little over a quarter of the 20- to 24-year olds are covered by current employer arranged superannuation, compared to over half of the 45- to 54-year-olds, and 56 per cent of 55- to 59-year-olds.

But the biggest discrepancy comes in a comparison of weekly earnings, where it is quite clear that the higher the earnings of employees, the more likely they are to be covered by employer arranged superannuation, irrespective of gender. I say irrespective of gender, knowing that in those higher echelons there are only a minority of women. Nevertheless, when they get there they are also able to be covered by these employer arranged schemes. Only a little over 3 per cent of employees earning under $120 a week are covered, compared with over 70 per cent of those earning $520 or more a week. At the very top levels of management, executives with an average salary of $300,000 per year before retirement, are eligible to receive a lump sum payout of $2.1m. Such executives of course have an incentive to receive part of their salary as payment to a superannuation fund I point out that that is not taxed, rather than as income, which is.

So to argue that there is any current equity in the superannuation scheme is to ignore the fact that the higher one's income, the higher one's position in the employment ladder, the greater one's chances are of receiving taxpayer subsidised benefits for one's retirement and, of course, since large numbers of them are received in lump sums, there is the potential to spend that on a luxurious home and to set oneself up nicely with enough investment to bring in a weekly income that does not cut one out of receiving the pension, and then to go on to a consolidated revenue sourced welfare payment.
I welcome the fact that Senator Messner has raised this issue today, because I think it is something that the electorate generally and members and senators do have to consider, and do it soon.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is no wonder, as indicated by Senator Walsh's speech in this debate earlier today, that the Government is running scared on the issue of superannuation taxation, because as this matter of public importance states, there is widespread alarm in the community concerning the Government's threat to tax people's superannuation. SPEECH.PARA: Quite simply, the Government has placed thousands of Australians who are about to retire, who are thinking of retiring soon or who are planning for their retirement at some future date, into a tailspin of uncertainty. Destroying superannuation will not solve the problems of excessive taxation. Destroying superannuation will only create further problems for the whole of Australia. TALK.START.PARA: —None of them will be affected.
—According to the Minister for Social Security, they are all cheats. They certainly will be affected if these proposals go ahead, Senator Bolkus.

SPEECH.PARA: It is probably fair to say that the people of Australia regard the Hawke Government as the biggest tax cheat that this nation has ever seen. It has been into people's pockets to such an extent that it is one of the major reasons that the standard of living of ordinary Australians has fallen. It has frozen tax thresholds, pushed low income earners into high income tax brackets, grabbed their money and set about engineering a fall in the living standards of all Australians. If there is any reference to people being tax cheats, I am sure that the people of Australia-particularly the people of Port Adelaide-will say that that is a description that should apply to the Government rather than to those people who have sought to provide for their future by taking out superannuation.

The superannuation proposals are nothing more than a reflection of the Hawke Government's inability to discipline its spending and provide sound economic management. As at May 1988, the Government will have only one fundamental objective: to take from superannuation every possible tax cent that it can get. Of course, the Australian people are sick and tired of that. The Government is saying, `Join a 3 per cent productivity scheme; get into superannuation. We want people to save for their long term financial security in retirement'. But beneath the reality one detects its hidden agenda. What the Labor Government really wants to say to people is, `Join a superannuation scheme so that we can tax you more'. The retirement incomes of employees will be sabotaged to enhance the after-tax profits of big business.

Senator Haines, in her remarks, made reference to the fact that blue-collar workers are not affected by this issue. As a result of the 3 per cent productivity provision, an increasing number of blue-collar workers are now entering superannuation schemes. We are to have new taxes on superannuation in May and then, in June or later, a report from Dr Cass telling us how superannuation can fit into retirement income policy. Nobody can predict what will happen tomorrow, let alone next week. However, the Government approaches this issue as if all that counts is the operation of its tax and revenue system-irrespective of the needs of different people-without recognising the dehumanising effects of such arbitrary legislation. The very great majority of people who take out superannuation do so many years in advance of their expectations of gaining benefit from it-20, 30, 40 or more years hence. On the other hand, their children may have done well and be financially secure in their own right. Their spouses may be healthy and secure or in ill health and requiring special care.
