Only now, at the eleventh hour, they find the choices they expected to have suddenly reduced, through the hidden agenda of this Labor Government. There are two areas of extreme financial uncertainty to the ordinary Australian-two areas vital to our society. Those are the purchase of a home and provision for old age. It is most annoying and frustrating to people that, whereas almost anything else can be purchased at a set price and under stable conditions, those two things cannot be. Simply at the stroke of a pen, it seems to many people, the Labor Government could mess up the carefully laid plans of years and dash an entire family's hopes because the Government has fouled up along the line and the public has to pay for its short-sightedness.

Is it right that a hardworking citizen can do everything expected for decades, only at the eleventh hour of life to discover that someone in Canberra has changed the rules and a life-time's plans go down the drain? If superannuation rules are changed people will not have enough to do what they have been encouraged to save for for most of their lives; they will have to start all over again. Even for younger taxpayers who have their lives in front of them and more time to adjust to any philosophy of saving that might arise from these changes, tax on superannuation, whichever way it is levied, smacks of a tax on tax and being an insidious degradation of human entitlement. The original ethic of superannuation was to encourage a stable work force and reward diligence and thrift.

All this proposed tax will do is encourage more and more people to opt out of superannuation and into social welfare or investment schemes other than superannuation which will guarantee that the same rules apply 30 years down the road. This is what the Government is all about-removing incentives, reducing everybody to a common denominator, making everyone dependent on and subservient to the state, turning the system into a cold numbers game where individual excellence and effort mean nothing, simply aiming to keep the ledgers balanced at all costs and, of course, looking after its mates. That is what is being done to Australia by a government which has been shrewd enough to make accommodation with a few of the super rich and with the powerful minority who control the work force but which has lost touch with and the faith of the people.

Quality of life means nothing if life ends badly. In not too many more years most of Australia's population will be in the latter half of life. A third of South Australia's population will be in that category in about two decades. So legislation on superannuation today will have a far greater bearing on and importance to Australian society then because that is when the maximum effect will be felt by people who are about 40 years of age today and halfway through their lives. Today's 20-year-olds will find themselves in the same position provided the rules are not changed again before then.

The Government should be trying to offer the decent, industrious people of Australia more options and more incentive to provide for their retirement years-not less. On regular occasions politicians have been accused of having three-year foresight-from one election to the next. But this Government has by-election foresight. It keeps its decisions from the people until its by-elections are out of the way in the current mess of political circumstances in which it finds itself. As I said, what we need in the superannuation system is additional incentive, not repressive penalty. As Senator Haines mentioned, in the past women have largely been locked out of superannuation, largely because they make up 81 per cent of the part time work force. Less than 8 per cent of part time employees have superannuation. Again, we need more incentive in the system to encourage women to enter into superannuation so that they also can provide adequately for their retirement.

This proposed tax is most damaging to the Australian community and, indeed, to the capacity of the Government to provide for those in need in future years because it will result in more claims on government social security revenue in the future. The only way this nonsense can be stopped is by the people of Port Adelaide voting Liberal tomorrow.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an interesting matter that has been raised for discussion today. It is interesting because it has been brought forward by the Opposition in the context of the Port Adelaide by-election which is to take place tomorrow. This being a political chamber it is understandable that the Opposition would bring forward matters which it thought might improve the case that it will put to the electors to decide upon tomorrow or to try to damage the opponent's case-that is the case that the Government has put forward.

SPEECH.PARA: The very interesting thing about this matter is that it is all built on supposition. Tomorrow the people have to decide between two parties. One party, the Opposition, is coming forward within 24 hours of the election and putting forward not a policy that it will want to pursue, not something positive and not something that might give the people of Port Adelaide hope, but an attack-not on government policies or government programs-but on what it says the Government might do.

How bankrupt is the Opposition when it is unable, within 24 hours of a by-election, to bring forward any positive policies and it is unable-and this is the significant point-to attack any Government policy at all? Senator Parer is to speak after me.

TALK.START.PARA: —And he will make a good speech, too.

—Of course he will make a good speech. I want him to tell me in that speech why his side has not been prepared to take on any Government policy and why it has not been prepared to put forward its own.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask the Senate to look at the matters that the Opposition could have discussed within 24 hours of an important by-election in South Australia. The Opposition made no attack on Government policies in respect of the economy, wages, industrial relations, social security, conservation, industry or consumer protection. I note that Senator Bolkus from South Australia is in the chamber. The Opposition has not attacked any policy that he has put forward or anything that he has done. The issue I am talking about is a by-election in Adelaide, the city which Senator Bolkus so ably represents. I also notice that Senator Foreman has come into the chamber because of his concern for the city of Adelaide. But no attack has been made on the consumer affairs portfolio which the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus), from South Australia, represents. The Opposition has made no attack on Government policy in respect of Aboriginals, health, community services, youth or employment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or ethnic affairs.

—I thank Senator Bolkus. The Opposition has made no attack on the ethnic affairs policy of this Government. Why is it-and Senator Parer has the opportunity to answer this because he is next to speak-that the side that the honourable senator represents is unable to find any Government policy to attack? Why is it that the Opposition has to turn to what it says this Government might do? Senator Jones will appreciate this: why is it that, on the day before the Port Adelaide by-election, the Opposition comes into this chamber and is unable to attack any policy this Government pursues or put forward any policy of its own which might give the people of Port Adelaide some hope? It is an attack aimed at rousing the fears of people. The Opposition is adopting the politics of fear and ignoring the politics of hope. One would have hoped that the Opposition would have come in here and said, `Look, this is our plan for the electorate of Port Adelaide'.
—They have no policies.

—That is the only conclusion that we can draw. Can Senator Foreman, who is in the chamber at the moment, think of anything positive that the Opposition has put forward for the people of the electorate of Port Adelaide?
—Absolutely nothing.

—The Opposition says, `Mr Howe and this Government are going to attack superannuation'. Let me make it quite clear from the start that the Opposition has raised a very important issue. What has this Government said about superannuation? Honourable senators are aware of what the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) had to say about superannuation, but it is worth repeating. He said that the Government will not consider-it will not even consider; it is not a matter of not adopting-any changes that will have an adverse impact on superannuation benefits that have already been accrued. What that means-and the guarantee is absolute-is that whatever people now have will not be subject to any attack. They will be able to keep what they have.
—What sort of guarantee is that?

—That is a good question. It is a guarantee given by a government which has produced a growth in employment of about a million jobs and an increase in pensions to almost 25 per cent of average weekly earnings.
—That is because real wages have fallen.

—That indicates what this movement is all about. It is to the credit of the many workers in Port Adelaide that they have shown, as workers, as true Australians, a capacity to make sacrifices for this country. They have taken a fall in wages which has increased employment and set this nation on the road to recovery. This Government will ensure that the workers of Port Adelaide benefit from its economic policies because they have made the sacrifices which the Labor movement, including the union movement, has asked them to make in the interests of the country. Senator Parer, the next speaker, when considering the position of the people in Port Adelaide might explain the anti-union activity which, unfortunately, because of his background, he supports in this chamber. Fundamentally he is a decent sort of a man but he has a blind spot in this area. He attacks union superannuation and says that unions should not run their own superannuation funds.
—He does not say that at all.

—Senator Messner, in his speech, said that he thinks union superannuation is all right, as long as it is properly managed and as long as the unions do not have a part in its management. What sort of attitude to the workers' representatives, to the unions of this country, is it to say that they are not able to run a superannuation fund? That is what the honourable senator implied. I hope he has looked at the union superannuation fund run by the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union in Victoria-an outstanding example of how workers, through their unions, can run their own funds. Yet Senator Messner and Senator Parer attack the capacity of the workers to control their own funds. That is the sort of thing they say about superannuation. That is the sort of attitude they have to the workers of Port Adelaide.

SPEECH.PARA: So pensions have risen from 22.7 of average weekly earnings, in 1983, when this Government came to office, to almost 25 per cent of average weekly earnings today. It is true that generous restraint has been shown by the workers of this nation. This is the Government which will look after the workers and protect them in the future, and it has the policies to do so.

Let us consider where we stand on this issue. Senator Parer will probably tell us what he believes about the ability of workers to look after their conditions. What does he say about penalty rates, overtime, and the ability of workers to earn extra when they work longer? What does he say about work practices and the capacity of workers to control their own future, to work in decent conditions and to get a decent wage, including overtime and penalty rates when they are earned?

Why has the Opposition suddenly become enamoured of workers whom it cast onto the scrap heap when it was last in government? I ask Senator Parer why the only time there was negative growth in this country since the war was while his Party was in power and why, in just over 12 months, more than 300,000 Australians in the prime of their working lives were thrown out of work and onto the scrap heap. The results are still evident. People in the prime of life, with families to keep and children to educate, were cast onto the scrap heap. Contrast that with the fact that this Government has created one million jobs.

Let us have a look at what this Government has done for pensioners, for people who are getting on in life. In the few minutes I have left, I shall outline the facts. This Government has put money back into the pockets of pensioners. It has added $40 to the pension since 1983 and the pension is now 25 per cent of average weekly earnings. In real terms this Government has increased pensions by 8.4 per cent. That is in contrast to the Liberals' callous disregard for pensioners which saw the pension rate drop in real terms by 2.4 per cent. Perhaps Senator Parer could explain why, under his regime, the pension rate dropped by 2.4 per cent, while under this Government it has risen by 8.4 per cent. The maximum rent assistance for age and other pensioners has been raised from $10 to $15 a week. In addition to twice-yearly pension indexations, the Government has now raised the income limit eligibility for pensioner health benefit cards according to the rise in the cost of living. In December 1985 the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) set up the first government review of social security in the last 40 years.

All this is evidence of this Government's concern for the working people of Australia-those sorts of people who live specifically in the Port Adelaide electorate and to whom this debate today is directed by the Opposition. We have done many very positive things, the sorts of things that give those people hope and the ability to say that there is a positive future ahead. The Government has been very positive in its approach, both to the economy and to social security benefits. In contrast, the Liberal Party has displayed a negative approach to life. Again, I ask Senator Parer to answer a question: Why has his leader, Mr Howard, promised to abolish labour market programs so that there is no chance of people ever getting work again? What does he propose to do to reverse these tragedies which have been imposed upon the people? He will cut unemployment benefits. He has said there will be big savings in social security expenditure. Where will that come from? What is he going to do about the consumption tax? Will he load a consumption tax on the people of Port Adelaide and make their goods more expensive than they are now? Will the Party follow John Elliott? What is Senator Parer's position on that matter?

Given this negative debate-negative in the sense that it is proposed by the Opposition, which relies on fear to win the seat of Port Adelaide-what does Senator Parer say about the very positive policies that this Government has put into operation? Why was he not prepared to debate those areas as distinct from what--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating a matter of public importance, raised by my colleague Senator Messner, on the widespread alarm in the community concerning the Government's threat to tax superannuation. It would give me great joy to respond to the many questions asked by Senator Cooney; his invitation to attack a range of lousy Hawke Labor Government policies. I would be delighted, but to do so would be to move away from the matter of public importance so I will just mention a few. First, reduced standards of living have been brought about by this Government. Ask anyone out there who goes to the supermarket. The high inflation rates has persisted in Australia despite what has happened overseas-it is more than double that of overseas countries. During the present Government's period in office we have had the highest interest rates in our history, which has affected the mortgage rates of everyone buying a house. This is also the highest taxing government in Australia's history. I mention those facts because Senator Cooney invited me to make a few comments about the sort of policies that could be attacked if we had the time. But we are talking about superannuation.

SPEECH.PARA: Superannuation is basically a simple process but it is not understood by the majority of people. That is why we have highlighted it. If people do not really understand such things the Government can zero in and take their savings away from them. Superannuation is simply savings made by individuals in their working lifetime to provide for their own retirement. That is what superannuation is-nothing more, nothing less.

A variety of funds are set up to achieve this, with different end products. For example, one is a benefit promise program in which the pay-out at the end is a guaranteed multiplier or percentage of final average salary as a lump sum or as a pension. These are mainly employer-employee funded and have to be checked from year to year to make sure that they are actuarially sound so that when a contributor retires the fund can make the proper pay-out. The second type of fund is the accumulation or occupational type fund. In such funds contributions are made by an employer or employee, or both, and the pay- out on retirement depends simply on how the funds have performed-what sort of interest factors there have been, what sort of returns have been received over the time the funds have been invested. Finally there is what is known as the 23fb fund. Such funds are available to self-employed people, who may make a tax deductible contribution of up to $1,500 a year for their superannuation.

Apart from the obvious benefit to the community of individuals paying for their own retirement, there is the added benefit that contributions represent savings and thus investment rather than consumption spending. The question we have to ask is-I think everyone who does not really understand superannuation should listen to this-what is the current tax position on superannuation? This is vitally important as the tax incentive is what encourages Australians in their working lifetime to put money aside for their retirement. As it now stands, employer contributions are tax deductible in respect of pay as you earn taxpayers. Employee contributions are no longer deductible because the Hawke Government removed tax deductibility of employee contributions. As I said, contributions of up to $1,500 a year to 23fb funds are deductible for self-employed people. Income from investments of superannuation contributions are not taxed. This maximises the pay- out on retirement. If a lump sum is taken on retirement, tax is levied at the rate of 15 per cent on the first $55,000 and at 30 per cent for any amount over that. Of course, the recipients also have to pay the Medicare levy on the lump sum. Senator Walsh mentioned that under the Liberal Government tax was paid on only 5 per cent of the lump sum.

The Government has calculated that tax incentives for people who contribute to their retirement, use their savings, are about $3.5 billion a year and it wants to get its fingers onto those savings of ordinary Australians. Government members are not the only ones; the Australian Council of Trade Unions, which is supposed to represent the aspirations of the working man, has proposed in its publication Australia Reconstructed that superannuation savings of individuals be offered to companies the ACTU supports at low interest rates. Not only has the Hawke Government lost touch with the battler; so has the ACTU. Money that would be earning, say, around 15 per cent would be offered at a much lower rate to business to the detriment of the wage earner, whose payment on retirement would thus be substantially less.

The Government has said that the taxing of superannuation is under review. Notwithstanding repeated questions about what it has in mind, the out of touch Hawke Government refuses to come clean. All Senator Walsh could do was launch an attack on Senator Jocelyn Newman. He evaded the question altogether. He made a cowardly attack on a very fine lady. The refusal of the Government to come clean has caused enormous concern and confusion in the minds of every Australian who has superannuation entitlements, whether it be in the near future or down the track. In addition, I understand that new contributors to self-funding of their retirement have virtually dried up. It is what the Australian, in its editorial today, calls a `superannuation mess'. It is worth quoting from that editorial. It states:
The Federal Government has still given no solid indication of its intentions regarding the possible imposition of a tax or taxes on superannuation.
It further states:

Although the Opposition's persistence . . . is completely justified in pointing to the muddle which now surrounds superannuation in this country and the economic and social costs of not clearing up the muddle, responsibility for most of which can be attributed to the present Government.

What can the Government do? It can do a lot of things to get at one's savings. Bear in mind that contributions to superannuation funds, people's entitlements, are their own savings. They are savings for retirement. I will mention two things the Government can do. Firstly, it can remove the tax deduction for employer contributions or charge a fringe benefits tax, as has occurred in New Zealand in recent months. This would really affect only the average income earner as it would be a disincentive to employer contributions to occupational funds. Secondly, it can tax the income of superannuation funds. The effect of this would again be to the disadvantage of the average income earner as it would automatically reduce the amount of money available on retirement. Let me give the Senate an example. If a person, his employer, or a combination of both, contributed $1,000 per year-$20 a week-over 25 years to a fund which earned 15 per cent a year, currently untaxed, he could expect a pay-out of $244,700. The introduction of a new 15 per cent tax on superannuation fund investments would mean that the individual would receive $168,788, a loss of $75,924 to the individual. This Government would steal just on $76,000 of savings from the individual which he would normally use in his retirement. The Government can also introduce a retrospective tax on lump sum pay-outs. I would say that nothing was beyond this Government.

The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and his Government have lost touch with what he and Senator Richardson referred to as the `common people', a term that I believe to be quite derogatory and that I and most Australians would find totally offensive. The term `common Australian' used by Senator Richardson and used in articles about the Prime Minister smacks of George Orwell's great book Animal Farm and a statement in that book when the pigs took control. Those honourable senators who have read the book might remember this statement: `Everyone is equal but some are more equal than others'. As an indication of how this Government has lost touch, the former member for Port Adelaide, Mick Young, went around his electorate holding himself out to be the champion of the working man. He retired from Parliament and collected a massive superannuation pay-out. He picked up a consultancy job with Qantas Airways Ltd at around $1,000 a day, but he was not content with that, so the Prime Minister rang around the business community for more jobs for Mick Young. Yet the same Prime Minister has the gall to write 50,000 letters to Australian Labor Party members in an expensive self-promotion campaign saying:
Being a real Labor Government means helping the needy and we've done that. It means restraining the greedy and we've done that.

All I can say is that that is hypocrisy. What Mr Hawke says is not what he practises, and the whole of Australia knows it, as reflected in the results of recent elections. Families are battling to make ends meet and the Labor Government does not want to know about them. Certainly, measures have to be taken to encourage more people to contribute during their working lifetime to their retirement so that they are not a burden on the taxpayer of the day, but neither we nor the embattled wage earner will tolerate what appears to be the preferred option of this Government-I say `preferred' because we do not really know and the Government will not come clean-to impose a tax on the earnings of superannuation funds, people's savings, which will reduce quite substantially the amount of money due to a taxpayer on his retirement. It is all summed up in an article in today's Sydney Morning Herald by Robert Haupt, who says:
. . . the Micks and Bobs of this world look after each other in retirement; don't expect them to spare a thought for you.
